Although the Gleason score appears 3+5=8 with tertiary pattern 4, Gleason grading post androgen deprivation therapy is not recommended as treatment may result in tumour morphology with spurious and misleading higher grade appearances and may not be predict
arances and may not be predictive of prognosis.

The carcinoma extends to the anterior margin across a front of 0.3mm (A25L3) in the anterior mid prostate, inferiorly.  At this location the advancing edge shows dispersed, often single cell infiltration and it is very difficult to distinguish tumour cells

lt to distinguish tumour cells from background inflammatory cells, due to lack of typical carcinoma morphology (cytoplasmic clearing, nuclear pyknosis and loss of nucleoli) related to androgen deprivation therapy.  However a keratin immunostain (AE1/AE3) h

eratin immunostain (AE1/AE3) highlights single cells at the inked margin (ink on tumour cells) and the margin is best regarded as positive.  The P540S immunoperoxidase stains is also positive in single cells here, but there may be some background staining
y be some background staining of non-neoplastic cells.  Multiple levels have been reviewed.  Elsewhere, including at the base in the area of extraprostatic extension, the margins are clear.

lcerated mucosa.  The tumour invades fibrous tissue in proximity to the portal vein wall but no mural smooth muscle invasion is seen. There is also extrapancreatic invasion into adipose tissue posteriorly (perineural spread) and into adipose tissue between

nd into adipose tissue between the duodenal wall and pancreas superiorly (contiguous invasion and perineural spread).  Extensiveperineural invasion is present both within the confines of tumour and as outlying foci.  A focus of mural vascular invasion is p

f mural vascular invasion is present and foci suspicious for lymphovascular invasion present, including within the duodenal wall.  Retractionartefact around tumour does make assessment of lymphovascular invasion difficult.

The pancreatic neck margin is 0.2mm from tumour, the portal vein margin <0.1mm from tumour (with perineural invasion 0.2mm from this margin) while the portal vein wall resection margins is at least 0.5mm from tumour (some sectioning disruption of this marg

ioning disruption of this margin limits assessment). The periuncinate margin is >5.5mm clear and the posterior retroperitoneal surface is 4mm clear.  The extrahepatic common bile duct, duodenal and gastric margins are all well clear.
clear.

The pancreas shows associated changes of chronic pancreatitis with ductolobular atrophy, fibrosis and chronic inflammation.  Away from the tumour there is mucinous and goblet cell metaplasia of ductules and focal mucinous metaplasia with micropapillae form

plasia with micropapillae formation in a larger duct (PanIN/L 1B).  Changes consistent with previous surgery are present with suture/foreign body granulomas with the greater omentum and serosa of stomach plus chronic inflammation and fat necrosis with admi

ion and fat necrosis with admixed giant cells within the peripancreatic fat.  The area of grey discolouration described in the greater omentum comprises fibrosis and suture granulomas.  Within adipose tissue posterior to the pancreas, there is also an absc

ancreas, there is also an abscess containing filamentous material suggestive of Actinomyces organisms.  The common bile duct shows mucosal erosions, mural acute inflammation and reactive epithelial atypia consistent with stent-related injury.  The gallblad
-related injury.  The gallbladder shows mucosal haemorrhage and mild chronic cholecystitis. A synoptic report for pancreatic exocrine carcinoma follows:

A.   Specimen labelled "Sarcoma left elbow, suture at 12 o'clock"consists of an orientated soft tissue mass, 100 x 120 x 40 mm.    There is an ellipse of skin, 44 x 120 mm with a suture denoting 12 o'clock identifies one apex of the ellipse.   There is a c

of the ellipse.   There is a central swellingdeep to the ellipse and extending into the underlying subcutaneous tissue in a multinodular lobated fashion.   There is focally very thin normal subcutaneous fat at the superficial margin and at the deep margin

margin and at the deep margin there is a thin layer of loose fibrous type tissue, consistent with tissue spanning a tissue plane of the fascia.    The lateral superficial margin inked blue, medial green and deep black.    Sectioning reveals a pale grey mul

ioning reveals a pale grey multinodular tumour which is mostly solid but also shows central cystic degeneration with myxoid material.   It appears to be circumscribed and measures 70 x 90 x 28mm.   Tumour reaches very close to the deep, medial superficial
the deep, medial superficial and lateral superficial margins (less than 1 mm).    The superior and inferior soft tissue margins appear clear (greater than 10 mm each).

B.    Specimen labelled "New superficial margin, 2 to 6 o'clock, suture at 12 o'clock" consists of an orientated ellipse of skin, 12 x 90 x 3mm.    A suture is identified at one apex identifying 12 o'clock.   There is no scar in the skin and no obvious abn

in the skin and no obvious abnormality.    9 o'clock half blue, 6 o'clock half black.    Block 1- TS 12 o'clock margin; 2 to 6 - serial TS from superior to inferior; 7 - TS 6 o'clock margin.   AE seven blocks.    (RA/JB)   10.8.56

A.  The tumour is a subcutaneous leiomyosarcoma which appears of a higher grade than that reported on the core biopsy (see 20G60877).  There are focal areas of necrosis but well below 50% (score 1).  The mitotic rate is focally very high particularly at th

y very high particularly at the advancing edge and in these areas the count exceeds 20/10 HPF (score 3).  The tumour is therefore of grade 3 - total score 6 (tumour differentiation -2, mitoses count -3, tumour necrosis - 1).

The tumour is well circumscribed but with outlying nodules, and the sarcoma extends to, but does not infiltrate dermis.  The surgical margins appear close but clear superficially and deep.  The deep and superficial margins are 0.5mm clear in focal areas.
0.5mm clear in focal areas.  No venous or perineural invasion is identified.  The superior and inferior margins are well clear.

B. Sections show a simple cyst lined by a single layer of cuboidal mesothelial cells with positive staining for calretinin and CK5/6. The findings are in keeping with a peritoneal inclusion cyst.  The attached fallopian tube appears unremarkable.  No ovari
ppears unremarkable.  No ovarian tissue is identified in the specimen.

ior peritoneal resection is at the distal margin.  The serosal surface contains some fibrous adhesions.  A polypoid tumour is present in the posterior wall of the upper rectum measuring 25 x 23mm.  The tumour is located 18mm from the distal margin. The rad

rom the distal margin. The radial margin is > 10mm clear.  No other mucosal lesions are identified. Proximal margin inked blue, distal margininked black, radial margin inked green.  On sectioning no definite invasion of the muscularis propria is seen.
scularis propria is seen.

mour. The right fallopian tube measures 60mm in length with a maximum diameter of 13mm.  The right ovary measures 45 x 30 x 25mm.  The cut surface of the right ovary contains solid and cystic areas, the solid areas constitute approximately 50% of the volum

approximately 50% of the volume and have a smooth cream cut surface.  The left fallopian tube measures 60mm in length with a maximum diameter of 8mm.  The left ovary measures 45 x 20 x 25mm.  The cut surface of the left ovary has a solid and cystic appeara

ma. Numerous highly atypical, bizarre multinucleated tumour cells are seen. In some areas, hyalinised bands of osteoid-like material separate malignant tumour cells (osteoid present in approximately 10% of tumour). Focal chondroid matrix and calcified bone

ounding fibroadipose tissue and skeletal muscle, and numerous degenerate skeletal muscle fibres are seen. The surrounding adipose tissue contains scattered atypical cells, however, no lipoblasts are identified. Background epidermal and dermocutaneous chang
ermal and dermocutaneous changes in keeping with history of previous radiotherapy are seen. An incidental benign naevus (clear of margins) is present.

The 40mm subcutaneous righttrapezius tumour is a high grade malignant sarcomatoid tumour. The overall morphology and pattern of immunohistochemical staining are those of a high grade pleomorphic sarcoma with focal osteosarcomatous component (approximately
tous component (approximately 10%).

The surrounding adipose tissue contains scattered atypical stellate cells, with smudgy chromatin and cytoplasm and variably prominent nucleoli. The possibility of a dedifferentiated liposarcoma has been considered and cannotbe entirely excluded. However, t

entirely excluded. However, the atypia in the surrounding adipose tissue may represent single cell infiltration of fat by malignant sarcoma cells, or alternatively, radiotherapy induced atypia. However, as a dedifferentiated liposarcoma cannot be entirely
liposarcoma cannot be entirely excluded, FISH testing for MDM2 amplification may be useful if clinically indicated.

A. The right ovarian parenchyma shows diffuse involvement by a well differentiated mucinous tumour. The mucinous tumour displays positive staining with CDX2 and CK 20, and negative staining with CK 7.This immunohistochemical profile is consistent with a tu

he left fallopian tube shows a 1mm focus of carcinoma in situ/high grade dysplasia (Block B9). The left ovary shows no significant abnormality.

C. The appendix has been totally blocked and examined in its entirety. The appendix shows close to total replacement of its normal mucosa with a mostly flat and focally undulating mucinous epithelial proliferation. The mucinous epithelium shows mild cytolo

s epithelium shows mild cytological atypia and mitoses are not prominent. The wall of the appendix displays an altered morphology in areas and appears fibrotic and hyalinised. There is no discernible lamina propria. Diverticula of the tumour areseen focall

a of the tumour areseen focally but there is no evidence of rupture or invasion. The appearance is consistent with a low grade appendiceal mucinous neoplasm. Normal looking colonic mucosa is seen at the resection margin of the specimen.
specimen.

yma shows no significant abnormality.

is consistent with pseudomyxoma peritonei although no epithelial component is identified.

COMMENT: In women with pseudomyxoma peritonei and concomitant ovarian and appendiceal tumours, recent immunohistochemical, molecular and genetic evidence supports an origin in the appendix in most cases, and secondary involvement of the peritoneum and ovar
ent of the peritoneum and ovaries (1).

The 85mm tumour is a spindle cell neoplasm with similar features to the previous excisions (24Y54792 and 24Y54792).  The tumour is relatively circumscribed with a thin fibrous pseudocapsule in areas, but also shows focal areas of infiltration into adjacent

of infiltration into adjacent hepatocellular parenchyma as well as entrapment of portal structures.  The cellulartumour shows a haphazard, sheet-like and focally storiform arrangement of spindle cells with densely eosinophilic, somewhat granular cytoplasm

c, somewhat granular cytoplasm, mild to moderate nuclear pleomorphism, finely granular chromatin and single to multiple small eosinophilic nucleoli.  The tumour contains red blood cell-filled pseudovascular spaces, as well as capillary size vessels.  Occas

ecific diagnosis was not possible.  The minimal patchy cytoplasmic CD117 staining with background hepatocellular staining in this case, is regarded as a negative result, especially in the context of previous negative DOG1 staining on two separate occasions
ning on two separate occasions.

ed bythis analysis, therefore a negative result should be interpreted with caution. Other mutations, either in the BRAF gene or in other genes, will not be detected by this analysis.

* This test does not specify the activating BRAF gene mutation that causes a substitution of the Valine at codon 600 (p.V600) of the BRAF protein. The test detects the common BRAFp.V600E (c.1799T>A) mutation, which occurs in >80% of BRAF positive tumours,

ed by this analysis, therefore a negative result should be interpreted with caution. Other mutations, either in the BRAF gene or in other genes, will not be detected by this analysis.

*This test has been shown in our laboratory to detect at least 5% mutant BRAF alleles in a background of normal DNA. Therefore a negative result should be interpreted with caution, as it does not exclude the presence of low levels of an activating BRAF mut
vels of an activating BRAF mutation.

The carcinoma largely effaces the cervical mucosa, has a maximum depth of invasion of 21mm and extends up to 30mm in length along the cervical canal. The carcinoma extends to the ectocervical, peripheral soft tissue margin and shows widespread involvement

shows widespread involvement of the defect (main specimen). CIN3 also extends to the ectocervical margin. There is widespread lymph-vascular space invasion and focal perineural involvement. No convincing glandular dysplasia is identified.
s identified.

In the separately received vaginal vault specimen, the superior portion shows extensive involvement by poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Carcinoma undermines the vaginal epithelium. Carcinoma is up to 22mm in thickness and infiltrates the full

kness and infiltrates the full thickness of the specimen toinvolve the superior soft tissue (peripheral) margins. Carcinoma is 8mm from the inferior margin. There is focal VAIN 3 which is clear of the margins.

The 25 sampled lymph nodes show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. However, many of the lymphnodes show at least partial effacement by enlarged neoplastic follicles, which consist predominantly of centrocytes. The neoplastic follicles are positive for CD

follicles are positive for CD10 and BCL-2; and are negative with T-cell markers (CD3, CD5, CD43) and cyclin D1. The neoplastic lymphoid infiltrate also shows focal extranodal extension. These morphologic and immunohistochemical features are consistent wit
al features are consistent with the history of known low grade non-Hodgkin's lymphoma of follicular subtype. There is no convincing evidence of high grade (large cell) lymphoma.

defined solid tumour measuring 70 x 50 x 40mm.  The tumour abuts the surgical margin.  The tumour is necrotic and cavitated.  Representative sections in six blocks (reserved block - block 6).

been largely destroyed and there is extranodal spread with carcinoma infiltrating muscle.  The surgical margins appear clear of the tumour with the closest margin being 0.5mm clear.  A few smaller adjacent lymph nodes negative for tumour are also present.
for tumour are also present.

the p16 immunoperoxidase stain is strongly positive (indicating HPV associated).

ur cells are separated by bands of hyalinised fibrotic stroma which stain negative for amyloid with Congo Red.  The tumour cells show strong positive staining for CK19 and TTF1, very patchy strong positive staining for HBME1 and negative staining for calci

nd negative staining for calcitonin.  The morphological appearance and immunohistochemicalprofile of the tumour are consistent with those of papillary thyroid carcinoma, oncocytic/Hurthle cell variant.  Carcinoma is 0.6 mm from the tracheal margin (Block A

s no stromal overgrowth, significant cytologic atypia or mitotic activity (less than 1 mitoses/hpf). The fibroepithelial lesion is surrounded by a variably thick cuff of fibroadipose breast tissue (0.25mm inareas) and focally extends to the inked margin. T
extends to the inked margin. There is no atypical ductal hyperplasia, DCIS or evidence of invasive malignancy.

B.  The right breast lesion is a fibroadenoma. The fibroadenoma is composed of benign ducts showing a mixed pericanalicular and intracanalicular pattern and surrounded by variably sclerotic fibrous stroma. The fibroadenoma extends to the inked/diathermied
ends to the inked/diathermied margins in areas. There are no atypical features or evidence of a phyllodes tumour. There is no atypical ductal hyperplasia, DCIS or evidence of invasive malignancy.

The 3 o'clock right breast lesion is a fibroepithelial tumour. The lesion has unusually high stromal cellularity, but there is no convincing stromal overgrowth, peri-ductal accentuation of cellularity, stromal cell atypia or significant mitotic activity (l

ignificant mitotic activity (less than 1 mitoses/hpf). Although a low grade Phyllodes tumour was considered in the differential diagnosis due to the high stromal cellularity, in the absence of any other atypical features the favoured diagnosis is a cellula
avoured diagnosis is a cellular (juvenile) fibroadenoma.

A.  Sections show a high grade endometrial carcinoma consisting predominately of sheets of tumour cells with pleomorphic nuclei containing vesicular chromatin and occasional prominent nucleoli.  Numerous multinucleated forms with occasional bizarre nuclear

ith occasional bizarre nuclear pleomorphism are seen.  Extensive mitoses and necrosis are present.  Focally admixed with the high grade tumour are deposits of endometrioid adenocarcinoma showing focal squamous differentiation.  Extensive carcinoma in situ

Extensive carcinoma in situ is also present of both endometrioid and serous type.  The tumour mainly forms an exophytic mass on the anterior wall of the uterus however, tumour invades to a depth of 10mm through a wall thickness of 16mm.  Focal lymphovasc

ess of 16mm.  Focal lymphovascular invasion is seen.  The endocervix is uninvolved and the ectocervix shows ulceration consistent with prolapse.  The overall features are that of a predominately anaplastic/undifferentiated carcinoma with focal endometrioid
cinoma with focal endometrioid and serous components.  The remainder of the uterus shows multiple calcified leiomyomas.

There are numerous CD4 positive Tcells in the tissue.  Most of these are associated with macrophages in areas of fibroblastic tissue and fat necrosis; these are interpreted as being part of a non-specific inflammatory reaction in the settingof previous che
in the settingof previous chemotherapy treatment.  However some CD4 positive cells are seen in intimate association with groups of residual, apparent viable, tumour cells.

There is also a moderate number of CD8 positive cells in the tissue (fewer than CD4 positive cells).  Almost all these cells are in areas of fibroblastic tissue and fat necrosis; there are only very occasional CD8 positive cells seen in association with re
ls seen in association with residual tumour.

Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for anyof the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch re
activation of that mismatch repair gene.

Sections show nodal tissue with effaced architecture consisting of atypical lymphoid follicles with some possible diffuse areas.  There is extension of lymphoid tissue into surrounding adipose tissue. The follicles consist of both small to medium sized cen
both small to medium sized centrocyte-like cells plus monocytoid-appearing cells. The number of centroblasts appears low (less than 5 per hpf).

Some lymphocytes within the atypical follicles show positive staining with CD10 however the monocytoid-appearing cells do not appear to stain.  Follicular dendritic cell networks are demonstrated with CD21 stain, possibly absent in focal diffuse areas.  Th

nt in focal diffuse areas.  The Ki67 index is approximately 30%.  The morphological appearanceand immunohistochemical profile are consistent with follicular lymphoma, grade 1.  The current case has similar appearances to the previous left groin lymph node

revious left groin lymph node (14U49554), however there now appears to be an additional infiltrate of monocytoid cells.  Monocytoid cells are seen occasionally within follicular lymphoma.  There is no evidence of transformation to high grade lymphoma withi
n to high grade lymphoma within this specimen.

Sections show fat depleted hypercellular parathyroid tissue composed predominantly of sheets of chief cells with some intervening transitional oncocyte and clear cell areas.  A portion of the tumour is invested in a fibrous capsule within which there are e

psule within which there are entrapped nests of parathyroid cells.  Scattered typical mitoses are seen (numbering up to 2 per 10 hpf) but no necrosis or significant nuclear pleomorphism is seen.  No definite transcapsular invasion, lymphovascular invasion
sion, lymphovascular invasion or perineural invasion is seen.  A small portion of adjacent normal parathyroid tissue is present.

The features are those of hypercellular parathyroid tissue weighing 350mg.  Providing the residual parathyroid glands are of normal size, the appearances are consistent with a parathyroid adenoma.  The area of fibrosis within and at the periphery of the no
and at the periphery of the nodule contains nests of parathyroid tissue, the latter strongly favoured to represent entrapment rather than capsular invasion.

Thank you for the opportunity to see the slides form this parathyroid.  The slides show a nodule of fat depleted parathyroid tissue with an adjacent rim of non-neoplastic parathyroid.  The features indicate parathyroid adenoma.  A little fibrosis is noted

.  A little fibrosis is noted at one edge extending into the gland.  This gives the appearance of regenerative change after an episode of cyst rupture/repair rather than representing invasive growth.  In this setting I would not consider it an atypical fin
ot consider it an atypical finding.

ncluding conspicuous plasma cells.  Numerous mast cells are also noted.  Scattered spindle and stellate cells display moderate nuclear atypia which may be degenerate in nature.  Occasional spindle cells display enlarged irregular hyperchromatic nuclei.  Oc

lar hyperchromatic nuclei.  Occasionalganglion-like cells and multinucleated cells are seen although no classic floret cells are present.  No ropey collagen, plexiform vasculature, cellular areas or necrosis is seen.  Peripherally in areas there is a thin
ally in areas there is a thin rim of skeletal muscle however, the tumour abuts the resection margin in several areas.

The differential diagnoses considered include a spindle cell lipoma with focal pleomorphic lipoma areas and well differentiated liposarcoma.  The features are not those of a neurofibroma.  In view of the location and overall appearances a diagnosis of spin

ppearances a diagnosis of spindle cell lipoma is favoured, however I cannot entirely exclude a well differentiated liposarcoma.  Tissue will be sent to BARWON HEALTH - ASHLEY MANOR CAMPUS'sHospital for MDM2 analysis and a supplementary report will be issue
lementary report will be issued.

A.  The entire specimen is embedded and examined.  Almost all the specimen comprises well differentiated liposarcoma which is mainly lipoma-like with some intervening sclerosing areas.  The tumour appears partly circumscribed with an overlying thin fibrous

with an overlying thin fibrous pseudocapsule. The lipoma-like areas show variation in adipocytes size, scattered hyperchromatic moderately pleomorphic nucleoli and easily identified lipoblasts.  The sclerosing areas comprise hypocellular fibrous bands cont

ypocellular fibrous bands containing atypical hyperchromatic stromal cells.  Skeletal muscle forms the deep margin of the specimen and sclerosing liposarcoma abuts but does not penetrate the muscle. Focally (A1) there is mild increase in cellularity of aty

increase in cellularity of atypical stromal cell, across 8mm. This focus, which reaches the superior margin at the junction with the deep margin, is interpreted as mildly cellular sclerosing liposarcoma, however, a low grade dedifferentiated component cann

edifferentiated component cannot entirely be excluded.  Focally (A9) there is a 4mm focus of circumscribed mineralised lamellar bone surrounded by sclerosing and lipoma-like osteosarcoma. The interconnected bony trabeculae show foci of rimming by moderatel

w foci of rimming by moderately pleomorphic hyperchromatic spindle cells and scattered atypical stromal cells are also present within the intertrabecular spaces.  The osteocytes within the trabeculae do not appear overtly atypical.  No parallel seams of wo
ical.  No parallel seams of woven bone or filigree osteoid are seen.  No high grade dedifferentiated tumour is seen.

There is widespread involvement of all surgical margins, apart from the deep margin, across a broad front.  Although a thin fibrous pseudocapsule covers most of the tumour (superficially, laterally and medially), the capsule contains atypical stromal cells

ontains atypical stromal cells consistent with sclerosingliposarcoma. There is intervening skeletal muscle between tumour and the deep margin with a minimal clearance of 0.5mm (A1), ,however, all the adjacent margins (superior, inferior, medial and lateral
, inferior, medial and lateral) are also involved close to the deepmargin. The focus of ossification (A9) is 5.6mm clear of the superficial margin and greater than 10mm from the other margins.

There is a 4mm focus of ossification within the well differentiated liposarcoma.  This focus is favoured to represent heterotopic ossification, however, as it merges with sclerosing liposarcoma and there are atypical intertrabecular stromal cells and atypi

ecular stromal cells and atypical spindle cells abutting the bone (? osteoblasts), I cannot exclude a microscopic focus of low grade osteosarcomatous dediffentiation.  No definite high grade dedifferentiation is seen.  In contrast the foci of ossification

rast the foci of ossification in the previous resction specimen (61K04161- 15,47), were grossly visible and showed either marked stromal atypia  in association with atypical mitoses or seams of osteoid in continuity with malignant osteoblasts, as opposed t
nant osteoblasts, as opposed to lamellar bone seen currently.

Two of the three tumours detected grossly are foci of mass forming high grade DCIS/pleomorphic LCIS.  Within some of the affected lobules there is colocalisation of high grade DCIS and pleomorphic lobular carcinoma within the same duct space with confirmat

same duct space with confirmatory positive and negative staining with E cadherin respectively (block 15). These two mass forming areas are located towardsthe inferior and central parts of the specimen.  The third more superiorly placed nodule is in fact an
ly placed nodule is in fact an intramammary lymph node (blocks 47 & 55) which shows no evidence of metastatic tumour in multiple levels examined or with a keratin immunostain.

The pleomorphic LCIS shows some apocrine features, foci of comedonecrosis and microcalcifications.  The high grade DCIS is also associated with calcifications to a lesser extent.  Although the calcification is mainly associated with mass forming areas of i

d with mass forming areas of in situ carcinoma all of the intervening slices also show dispersed foci of intermediate to high grade DCIS, often clinging type, which in most instances is unassociated with calcification.  There is also calcification associat

is also calcification associated with benign intraductal proliferations, mainly columnar cell alteration both with and without hyperplasia.  Some of the columnar cell foci showing superimposed architectural and cytological atypia amounting to atypical duct
pia amounting to atypical ductal hyperplasia.  Foci of flat epithelial atypia are also seen.

Miscellaneous: The breast tissue also shows extensive columnar cell change and columnar cell hyperplasia, both with and without hyperplasia. Scattered microcalcifications are present within these foci.  There are also columnar cell lesions with architectur
cell lesions with architectural and cytological atypia amounting to atypical ductal hyperplasia.

- 1.4mm infiltrating lobular carcinoma, ER (not assessable), PR positive, HER2 negative (no residual tissue for HER 2 CISH) plus multiple foci of microinvasive lobular carcinoma; ER positive in one of the latter.  CISH on a separate microinvasive focus to
parate microinvasive focus to follow.

A.  Sections show a relatively well circumscribed tumour with a nodular architecture divided by thick fibrous bands.  The tumour is comprised of nests, cords and in other areas dilated pseudoglandular spaces.  The cells are large with voluminous clear to e

rge with voluminous clear to eosinophilic granular and vacuolated cytoplasm with central nuclei, granular chromatin and frequent prominent nucleoli.  There is a large amount of cellular pleomorphism with wildly atypical cells seen.  Scattered cells have bi

seen.  Scattered cells have bile pigment within their cytoplasm.  Frequent mitoses including atypical forms are seen.  The tumour abuts the liver capsule but does not penetrate it.  The surgical resection margin is well clear (greater than 20mm) of tumour.
(greater than 20mm) of tumour.  Foci of lymphovascular invasion are seen.   The features are consistent with a moderate to poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma.

The surrounding liver shows a mild expansion of the portal tracts with fibrous tissue but no portal tract linkage, nodule formation or established cirrhosis.  There is a mild to moderate infiltrate of chronic inflammatory cells within the portal tracts con

s within the portal tracts consisting of lymphocytes and a smaller number of plasma cells.  Mild interface hepatitis is focally present.  No steatosis, ground glass hepatocytes of Hepatitis B infection, significant accumulation of iron, copper or alpha-1-a
n of iron, copper or alpha-1-antitrypsin globules is seen.  The features are non-specific.

A.  The sentinel lymph node contains a single tubular structure, less than 0.1mm in dimension, within the subcapsular sinus.  The tubule is lined by single layer of cells with mildly pleomorphic nuclei, small nucleoli and eosinophilic cytoplasm.  An occasi

nophilic cytoplasm.  An occasional giant cell is also seen nearby within the lymph node parenchyma. The cytological features of the cells of the tubule are similar to those of the previously excised invasive carcinoma (79D87572).  The tubule is only presen

2).  The tubule is only present in a single level and attempted analysis with a keratin immunostain following deparaffinisation and destaining of the H&E stained section is unsuccessful due to tissue disruption.  In a separate single level, away from the t

single level, away from the tubular focus, there are several nests of bland ovoid to spindle cells within the capsule of the lymph node. These cells have slightly irregular nuclei, pale chromatin and a rare intranuclear inclusion.  No mitosis are seen.  A

sion.  No mitosis are seen.  Attempted keratin immunostaining on these cells is also unsuccessful due to tissue disruption.  The routine CAM5.2 keratin immunostains (performed on levels not containing these foci) are negative.

The sentinel lymph node shows a single tubular structure with the subcapsular sinus, raising the possibility of involvement by isolated tumour cells.  However attempted analysis with keratin immunostains is non-contributory for technical reasons anddefinit
r technical reasons anddefinitive diagnosis is not possible.  An additional focus within the capsule of the lymph node is strongly favoured to represent a cluster of benign naevus cells.

Sections show a predominantly lipomatous lesion consisting of sheets of mature adipocytes with intervening areas of myxoid change containing collagen bundles, mast cells and plasma cells. Scattered hyperchromatic mildly to moderately atypical spindled to s

erately atypical spindled to stellate cells, including occasional bizarre floret-like giant cells, are also present. No convincing lipoblasts or significant variation in lipocyte size is seen. The lesion is partially surrounded by an incomplete, thin fibro

d by an incomplete, thin fibrous capsule and the tumour extends to the inked margins over a broad front. The tumour shows changes consistent with previous biopsy/surgical intervention and there is patchy fat necrosis.

The medial left thigh mass is a lipomatous tumour containing scattered atypical, hyperchromatic cells. The overall morphology and pattern of immunohistochemical staining favours a pleomorphic lipoma. However, despite the absence of lipoblasts and variation

ce of lipoblasts and variation in adipocyte size, the lower extremity is an unusual site for a pleomorphic lipoma (less than 5%), and the possibility of an atypical lipomatous tumour/well-differentiated liposarcoma cannot be excluded. FISH testing for chro
xcluded. FISH testing for chromosome 13/16 and MDM2 abnormalities would be useful to confirm the diagnosis.

r SMA, and desmin, ALK-1 and cytokeratin stains are negative. The overall histologic features favour hepatolithiasis with an obstructive cholangitis, large duct obstruction within the adjacent liver and a chronic active cholecystitis. However, the differen

ystitis. However, the differential diagnosis could also include an inflammatory pseudo-tumour; primary inflammatory bile duct disease; and although considered less likely, an infective etiology. Given the broad differential diagnosis, this case will be sen
agnosis, this case will be sent to Professor RANDOLPH HYSMITH at DAYSURGERY UNIT Pathologists, for his expert opinion, and an additional report will be issued.

Test description: This test profiles a broad range of somatic mutations from 19 common oncogenes (ABLI, AKTI, AKT2, BRAF CDK4, EGFR, ERBB2, FGFRI, FGFR3, FLT3, JAK2, KIT, MET, HRAS, KRAS, NRAS. PDGFA, PIK3CA and RET) using the OncoCarta TM panel v1.0. This

OncoCarta TM panel v1.0. This panel is intended to assist the selection of targeted therapies for cancer patients. Mutation analysis is performed on DNA isolated from FFPE tissue. The relevant target regions are amplified in 24 multiplex PCR reactions and

24 multiplex PCR reactions and the presence of mutation(s)is determined by a single nucleotide primer extension assay and analysed using mass spectrometry. Any reported mutation is called with high confidence (i.e. the proportion of a mutant allele is 10%

ion of a mutant allele is 10% or more). This oncogene panel can detect 238 mutations including the following clinically relevant mutations in the EGFR (NM_005228), KRAS (NM-004985) and BRAF(NM-004333) genes. For a full list of the 238 mutations tested, ple
the 238 mutations tested, please see http:/www.sequenom.com/home/products--- services/genetic-analysis/ applications/ oncocarta/

A.  The specimen has been entirely embedded and examined.  Sections show an 8mm hyperplastic benign follicular-patterned within the inferior third of the lobe.  The unencapsulated nodule has a macrofollicular architecture.  There is some patchy scalloping

ere is some patchy scalloping of colloid however no nuclear atypia is seen.  The background thyroid has an accentuated lobular architecture however no discrete nodules are seen.  No lymph nodes or parathyroid glands are identified.  There is no evidence of
fied.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

B.  The left lobe of thyroid has been entirely embedded and examined.  Within the upper third ofthe lobe there is a dominant hyperplastic adenomatoid nodule, approximately 15mm in maximum dimension which contains cellular microfollicular and nested Hurthle

ofollicular and nested Hurthle cell areas as well as non-metaplastic mainly macrofollicular areas.  The nodule is partially invested by thin fibrous tissue but lacks a distinct thick walled capsule.  Focally the Hurthle cell component displays some atypica

omponent displays some atypical features with nuclear crowding, nuclear grooves and mild chromatin pallor. There is corresponding membranous HBME1 expression in this focus, albeit with some non-specific backround staining.  Overall the atypical features ar

erall the atypical features are regarded as insufficient for a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma.  No significant mitotic activity, nuclear convolutions or necrosis is seen.  The background thyroid shows several hyperplastic nodules and foci of palpation th
dules and foci of palpation thyroiditis.  No lymph nodes or parathyroid glands are seen.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

The 15mm nodule is quite distinct from the remainder of the thyroid.There is subtle but real nuclear atypia indicated by nuclear grooving, loss of polarity and nuclear irregularity and no doubt this nuclear atypia accounts for the findings in the fine need

the findings in the fine needle aspirate.  Importantly this atypical nodule iscompletely encapsulated with no capsular or vascular invasion, confined to the thyroid and completely excised.  In reality this is probably a dysplastic nodule with the potentia

astic nodule with the potential to progress if left in situ.  Because there is no conceptof dysplasia in the thyroid and because it will be reliably cured by complete excision (as has been performed) I would classify it as a benign follicular adenoma.
enign follicular adenoma.

B.  Sections show a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma arising from the upper main bronchus.  The tumour is mainly exophytic in nature, filling the bronchus.  There is extension into the bronchial soft tissue, surrounding cartilage and infil

urrounding cartilage and infiltrating peribronchial glands, with minimal infiltration of alveolar tissue.  Focal lymphovascular invasion is identified but no perineural invasion is seen.  Adjacent carcinoma in situ is seen within the bronchus.  The tumour

hin the bronchus.  The tumour lies greater than 10mm from the bronchial resection margin and no pleural invasion is identified.   One (1) of the eight (8) hilar lymph nodes shows metastatic squamous cell carcinoma.

The lung parenchyma within the upper lobe shows no significant abnormality, however the lung parenchyma with in the lower lobe shows patchy interstitial fibrosis and chronic inflammation which includes moderate numbers of eosinophils.  Scattered loose fibr

nophils.  Scattered loose fibroblastic foci are seen.  There is extensive subpleural collapse and fibrosis.  Scattered stellate scars showing muscularisation are also present.  No definite CD1a histiocytes are seen.  Small granulomas are also present, some
nulomas are also present, some of which lie adjacent to intermediate sized blood vessels.  The significance of these findings within the lower lobe is uncertain and a further opinion will be sought.

Within the lower lobe there is an interstitial process.  Scattered through the lung there are numerous small stellate fibrotic scars that extend into the adjacent alveolar parenchyma.  Many of these scars are associated with relatively recent fibrosis and

elatively recent fibrosis and Masson body formation.  In addition to these changes small areas of the alveolar parenchyma show thickeningand contain a mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate.  Around the scars and within the thickened interstitial areas eosinop

ned interstitial areas eosinophils are relatively common and occasional small granulomas are seen.  The pleural is predominantly normal but in occasional areas pleural fibrosis with fibrosis of the underlying alveolar parenchyma has occurred.  Stains for S
ma has occurred.  Stains for S100 and CD1a are negative in that they fail to show Langerhan histiocytes within the foci of fibrosis.

Overall these changes are difficult to interpret.  The general morphological appearance of the stellate scars would be in keeping with a Langerhans histiocytosis but this is almost invariably a diffuse process and does not account for the lack of changeswi

ount for the lack of changeswithin the interstitium of the upper lobe.  The appearances are not those of a usual interstitial pneumonitis with good preservation of the subpleural alveolar parenchyma in many areas.  In addition true fibroblastic foci are no
true fibroblastic foci are not present.

Overall the appearances raise a relatively wide differential.  The changes could be due to an extrinsic allergic alveolitis with the lack of changes seen within the upper lobe accounted for by the blockage of the bronchi bytumour.  This would account for t
our.  This would account for the lack of diffuse changes.

Such changes raise the possibility of a Langerhans histiocytosis but this diagnosis cannot be sustained in the absence of demonstrating active Langerhan histiocytes in the affected areas.  In addition a Langerhans histiocytosis would be expected to be diff
s would be expected to be diffuse.

Such changes could be accounted for by an old viral infection such as chicken pox but again this does not explain the focal nature of the changes and does not explain the apparent immature fibrosis affecting many areas.  Overall I would interpret these cha

ll I would interpret these changes as probably representing a form of extrinsic allergic alveolitis.  The antigen eliciting this response is unknown and the possibility that is a tumour related phenomenon could be considered.

Specimen labelled "Left breast tissue long lateral, medium medial, short superior" consists of an irregular piece of fibrofatty tissue with three sutures for orientation measuring 30mm(medial to lateral) x 20mm (superior to inferior) x 20mm (superficial to

ferior) x 20mm (superficial to deep) margin.  The superior margin is inked blue, inferior margin black, superficial margin red, deep margin yellow.  Specimen is serially sectioned from lateral to medial.  On sectioning there is a white fibrous nodule measu
s a white fibrous nodule measuring 20 x 10 x 10mm.  AE from lateral to medial.

Sections show a fibroepithelial lesion characterised by an epithelial component arranged in clefts surrounded by an overgrowing mesenchymal component focally organised in leaf-like structures. The epithelial component shows a spectrum of proliferative chan

spectrum of proliferative changes including florid usual ductal hyperplasia, columnar cell change and atypical ductal hyperplasia. The stromal component is moderately cellular and shows varying degrees of fibrosis. There is mild to moderatecytological atyp

ld to moderatecytological atypia of the stromal spindle cells and a mitotic count of up to 3 per 10 high power fields is identified. Although the lesion is mostly circumscribed with a pushing border, irregular infiltration into the surrounding breast tissu
o the surrounding breast tissue is focally present. The morphological appearance is consistent with a borderline phyllodes tumour.

The remainder of the breast shows proliferative changes similar to that seen within the phyllodes tumour including florid usualductal hyperplasia, columnar cell change and atypical ductal hyperplasia. Definite diagnostic features of ductal carcinoma in sit
res of ductal carcinoma in situ are not identified. There is no evidence of invasive epithelial malignancy.

COMMENT: Fibroepithelial lesions are well known in their ability to induce proliferative changes in the overlying epithelium. However, given the widespread proliferative changes seen within the tumour and the surrounding breasttissue, it is best to regard
ttissue, it is best to regard some of these as atypical ductal hyperplasia given the presence of moderate cytological atypia and mitoses.

A. Sections show a circumscribed lesion in the liver composed of multiple dilated, angulated tubules.  The nuclear morphology is difficult to assess due to diathermy and frozen section artefact. While the majority of tubules are lined by epithelium with bl

n the some of the lumens. There is no bile present within the lesion.

The findings are of an atypical glandular proliferation. While the general consensus in the department favoured a bile duct hamartoma with reactive changes, some felt a well differentiated metastatic adenocarcinoma could not be excluded. Slides will be sen
e excluded. Slides will be sent to Professor LUCAS WOODLING, EASTERN EYRE HEALTH AND AGED CARE - COWELL CAMPUS Hospital for an expert opinion.

ngle tumour cells are also present. The tumour cells are positive for CK7 and TTF-1. PSA and CK20 are negative.

I agree with you and Haroun that the liver lesion biopsies in specimen A ("Liver lesion segment 4") is a benign bile duct proliferation.  In my opinion it is best classified as a biliary hamartoma (while the lesion in specimen B from segment 2 is a peribil
B from segment 2 is a peribiliary gland hamartoma/bile duct adenoma).

ts/tubules and the lesion is well circumscribed.  The cells lining the ducts display little anisonucleosis or nuclear pleomorphism, nucleoli are generally inconspicuous, mitoses scant and cytoplasmic borders are well defined.  This contrasts with the pancr
This contrasts with the pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma present in specimens B & E ('Pancreatic mass biopsy").

Sections show liver with 6mm deposit of metastatic large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma (WHO 2010). The lesion is composed of sheets of tumour cells with enlarged, ovoid nuclei, prominent nucleoli and clear to pale cytoplasm.  There are more than 50 mitoses
There are more than 50 mitoses per 10hpf. Focal necrosis is present.  The lesion extends to the edge of the specimen.  The adjacent uninvolved liver is unremarkable.

The previous duodenal biopsy from the primary lesion (66O28821) has been reviewed. The tumour cells in this biopsy have a similar morphology to the current specimen, and are also positive for CD56. The findings in the biopsy would be in keeping with large
ould be in keeping with large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma.

In additional, the tumour focally shows increased cellularity, and is composed of intersecting fascicles of spindle shaped tumour cells, with increased nuclear atypia and raised mitotic activity (up to 11 per 10 hpf, e.g. blocks 4 and 12). There are also s

ks 4 and 12). There are also significant areas of tumour necrosis involving approximately 10% of the lesion (Blocks 4, 14, 21). These areas would be in keeping with intermediate grade myxofibrosarcoma (myxoid malignant fibrous histiocytoma) arising from DF
histiocytoma) arising from DFSP.

The presence of focal tumour necrosis, high mitotic activity (11 per 10 hpf), nuclear atypia and increased cellularity is beyond that acceptable for dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) and would be in keeping with an intermediate grade myxofibrosarcoma
ediate grade myxofibrosarcoma (myxoid malignant fibrous histiocytoma) arising from DFSP.

al invasion.  There is lymphovascular invasion in the endometrium and also focally in the superficial myometrium.  There are also quite extensive small foci of calcification in small vessels throughout the myometrium, suggesting previous more extensive lym
ng previous more extensive lymphovascular invasion, now with treatment effect.  The endometrium and myometrium are otherwise unremarkable and the cervix is not involved.

Microscopic deposits of serous carcinoma are seen in both ovaries and at the fimbrial ends of both fallopian tubes; these are favoured to be metastatic from the endometrial tumour but could possibly have arisen as part of a field change of the Mullerian ep
eld change of the Mullerian epithelium.  Serous carcinoma is also seen in lymphovascular channels at the distal ends of both fallopian tubes.  No carcinoma in-situ of the tubal epithelium is seen.

s with large, irregular vesicular nuclei and eosinophilic or pale cytoplasm.  Some nuclei have a single prominent nucleolus.  The tumour is infiltrative at its periphery and there is some direct invasion into peripancreatic fat.  There is no tumour invasio

t.  There is no tumour invasion of the duodenalwall.  There is multifocal perineural invasion within and at the advancing edge of the tumour, but not outside the main tumour.  There is also multifocal lymphovascular invasion within and at the advancing edg

ithin and at the advancing edgeof the tumour.  No large vessel invasion is seen.  Main pancreatic ducts within the tumour show features of PAN-IN 3.  Pancreatic tissue adjacent to the tumour is atrophic.

ows a normal pattern in contrast. There is a heavy neutrophilic and focally lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory cell infiltrate within the lesion. Mitoses areinfrequent and no necrosis is seen.

A.  Sections of uterus show an endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma consists predominantly of infiltrative glands, many with a complex/cribriform architecture, lined by moderately pleomorphic carcinoma cells. Focally, small areas wit

ells. Focally, small areas with a non-squamous, non-morular solid growth pattern are present. The adenocarcinoma infiltrates to a maximum depth of 5.5mm, thorugh a uterine wall 11mm thick. No convincing lymphovascular space invasion or serosal involvement
vasion or serosal involvement is seen. The cervix, fallopian tubes and ovaries show no significant histologic abnormality.

The uterine tumour is an endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma. Although the initial endometrial curettings (04K99930) showed a predominant solid pattern of growth (FIGO Grade 3), examination ofthe entire endometrium shows the tumour is composed predomin

he tumour is composed predominantly of complex infiltrative cribriform glands. Overall, these findings are most consistent with a FIGO Grade 2 endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma (Architecture: grade 2 (5 - 50% solid growth); Cytology: grade 2).
h); Cytology: grade 2).

A & B. Sections show a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with signet ring differentiation.  The carcinoma displays a transmural sheet like growth of malignant cells with signet ring or more undifferentiated features. The latter show enlarged hyperchroma

tter show enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei, vesicular chromatin, prominent nucleoli and minimal to moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm.   No more differentiated component is seen in the mucosa, as may be seen with primary tumours.  Focal extracellular mucin is s

Focal extracellular mucin is seen. The tumour contiguously invades the mesenteric fat and there is serosal involvement (block A5) There is focal exophytic mucosa growth but no adjacent adenomatous component.  Extensive mucosal and submucosal lymphatic inva

and submucosal lymphatic invasion and focal intramural venous involvement (block A5) is present.  Twenty five (25) of thirty one (31) mesenteric ymph nodes are involved by metastatic adenocarcinoma, many of which are almost completely replaced.    All but

ompletely replaced.    All but one of the involved lymph nodes show foci of extra nodal extension which measure up 2mm in maximum dimension.  Foci of perineural invasion by extranodal tumour is also seen (block A9) and a focus of extranodal extension by tu

of extranodal extension by tumour also penetrates the adjacent serosa (block A12). There are also several peri nodal tumour deposits, presumably representing extralymphatic extension.  A subserosal component of the tumour extends to with 0.9mm of one long
ends to with 0.9mm of one longitudinal resection margin.

The features are those of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with signet ring differentiation.   Primary adenocarcinoma of the small intestine is extremely rare and more commonly occurs in the duodenum.  Gross and histological features may not be relia

ical features may not be reliable in distinguishing primary from metastatic adenocarcinoma in the small bowel.  There is also a degree of overlap in the CK7/CK20 immunoprofiles of primary versus metastatic adenocarcinoma.  No definite adjacent adenomatous

definite adjacent adenomatous component is seen and the mucosa away from the tumour shows no histological abnormalities.   The staining of tumour cells for both CK7 and CK20 somewhat favours a small bowel primary over metastasis from a colorectal primary/a

is from a colorectal primary/appendiceal, however, this immunoprofile is also consistent with metastasis from or upper gastrointestinal primary, such as the stomach.   Metastatic lung and prostate adenocarcinoma are unlikely in view of the negative TTF1 an
n view of the negative TTF1 and PSA immunostains respectively.   Clinical and radiological correlation is necessary.

Block 1- LS one colonic margin; 2- LS other colonic margin; 3 &#8211; TS colon directly above tumour (the tumour is non-adherent to the bowel wall); 4-10 &#8211; tumour and peritonealised surface; 11-25 &#8211; representative tumour, including

resentative tumour, including fibrous areas, presumed areas of necrosis, and possible fatty areas; 26-31 &#8211; representative sections of fatty and vascular tissue adjacent to marking suture; 32-40 &#8211; representative pericolic and mesenteric

A.  The 250mm tumour is a circumscribed unencapsulated spindle cell tumour, composed of mild to moderately pleomorphic spindle cells arranged in a storiform and pattern-less architecture, with scattered admixed haemangiopericytomatous (stag-horn like) vess

tomatous (stag-horn like) vessels. In areas, the cellularity is moderate to high. There are scattered mitoses, up to 15 per 10 hpf, and occasional foci of tumour associated necrosis. No marked cytologic atypia is seen. No convincing lymphovascular space in

incing lymphovascular space invasion is seen. Tumour focally abuts the peritonealised surface. There is patchy admixed mild chronic inflammation. The surrounding fibroadipose tissue shows mild variation in adipocyte size, however, no lipoblasts or cytologi
ver, no lipoblasts or cytologic atypia are seen.

Overall, the morphology and pattern of immunohistochemical staining identified at RECOVERY is consistent with the diagnosis of solitary fibrous tumour. The clinical behaviour of solitary fibrous tumours may be unpredictable, however, the large size, increa
owever, the large size, increased cellularity, high mitotic rate (&gt; 4/10 hpf) and presence of necrosis, portends more aggressive (malignant) behaviour in this case.

Given the retroperitoneal location of this tumour, the possibility of a STAT6 positive dedifferentiated liposarcoma with a solitary fibrous tumour-like morphology, cannot be entirely excluded1. Although no background features of liposarcoma are seen within
of liposarcoma are seen within the adjacent adipose tissue, if clinically indicated, supplementary FISH testing for MDM2 amplification can be arranged.

B.  The appendix has been examined in its entirety. The appendiceal lumen is expanded by a faecolith. There is no evidence of acute appendicitis. No pathogenic organisms or granulomas are identified. There is patchy acute serositis most likely related to i
sitis most likely related to intra-abdominal pathology. There is no evidence of malignancy.

Sections show fatty connective tissue with an overlying layer of peritoneal mesothelium. The subsurface tissue is extensively involved by an infiltrative malignancy which has a predominantly cystic pseudoglandular architecture. The spaces are lined by larg

. The spaces are lined by large epithelial cells with moderate amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei. The nuclei show variable atypia. There are some papillary structures present. In intervening stromal tissue there is a patchy chronic inf

there is a patchy chronic inflammatory infiltrate and there are some aggregates of foam cells. There are moderate numbers of tumour infiltrating lymphocytes. The subsurface epithelial proliferation merges with overlying mesothelial cells. Some cells conta
helial cells. Some cells contain cytoplasmic vacuoles.

Sections show fatty subperitoneal tissue with a surface layer of peritoneal mesothelium. There is a subsurface partly solid and partly cystic mass with a papillary, solid and pseudoglandular architecture of similar appearance to the tumour in specimen A (M

to the tumour in specimen A (MESOTHELIOMA). The subsurface lesion has an invasive growth pattern and involves much of the specimen. The cells have a variable decidoid appearance. There is a stromal inflammatory infiltrate of small lymphocytes in areas and

mall lymphocytes in areas and some xanthoma cells. Some psammoma bodies are present. There are moderate numbers of tumour infiltrating lymphocytes.  The tumour invades some attached skeletal muscle in one  section (C7). There is overlying mesothelial hyper
is overlying mesothelial hyperplasia, fibrous adhesions and areas of granulation tissue and in some areas there are aggregates of psammoma bodies.

Sections show fatty tissue with involvement by MESOTHELIOMA. There is deep invasion of subsurface fat. There are some sheets of foamy histiocytes associated with the tumour and a patchy chronic inflammatory infiltrate of small lymphocytes and plasma cells.
lymphocytes and plasma cells. The tumour cells have a decidual appearance.

The Immunohistochemical profile is consistent with mesothelioma. Immunohistochemical loss of nuclear BRCA-associated protein 1 (BAP1) is a highly specific marker of malignancy in mesothelial lesions. In the current case there are other diagnostic features
are other diagnostic features of malignancy (in particular deep invasion of subsurface tisssues).

helial cells. Some cells contain cytoplasmic vacuoles.

The Immunohistochemical profile is consistent with mesothelioma. Immunohistochemical loss of nuclear BRCA-associated protein 1 (BAP1) is a highly specific marker of malignancy in mesothelial lesions. In the current case there are other diagnostic features
are other diagnostic features of malignancy (in particular deep invasion of subsurface tisssues).

The depth of tumour invasion is difficult to assess as there is a florid fibroinflammatory reaction around the advancing edge of the tumour which merges with the muscularis propria. However, definite extension beyond the muscularis propria is identified in
laris propria is identified in block 5. Chronic inflammation and fibrosis are present extending to the serosa, but no definite tumour invasion of serosal fat is identified.

Numerous non-caseating epithelioid granulomas are present within the bowel wall adjacent to the transverse colon carcinoma. The section of bowel taken between the tumours shows no significant abnormality nor evidence of granulomatous inflammation, raising
omatous inflammation, raising the possibility that these changes are locally related to the presence of tumour. Similar granulomas are also identified within benign regional lymph nodes.

Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch r
nactivation of that mismatch repair gene.

THERAPEUTIC IMPLICATION: Tumours lacking mutations in KRAS or NRAS exons 2,3 or 4 are nipre likely to respond to anti-EGFR antibody therapy (Douillard et al NEJM 2013; 369:1023-34). The significance of BRAFV600E mutation as a predictive marker for anti-EGF
predictive marker for anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal carcinoma is controversial.

Although genetic testing is ultimately required to discriminate between Lynch syndrome and MSI-high sporadic  colorectal cancer (mostly associated with hypermethylation of the MLH1 gene promoter), the presence of a BRAF V600E gene mutation strongly support
gene mutation strongly supports a sporadic tumour (College of American Pathologists, Ed 1.1. Oct 2013).

This test profiles a broad range of somatic mutations from 4 common oncogenes (BRAF, EGFR, KRAS and NRAS) using OncoFOCUS&#8482; with additional custom panel. This multi-gene parallel profiling is intended to assist the selection of targeted therapies

lection of targeted therapies for cancer patients. Mutation analysis is performed on DNA isolated from tumour tissue. The relevant target regions are amplified in 2 multiplex PCR reactions followed by 12 multiplex extensions. Any mutant allele is accuratel

Any mutant allele is accurately identified by mass spectrometry. Any reported mutation is called with high confidence (i.e. the proportion of a mutant allele is 10% or more). This oncogene panel can detect over 300 mutations including the following clinica

ncluding the following clinically relevant mutations in the EGFR (NM&#173;_005228), KRAS (NM_004985), BRAF (NM_004333) and NRAS (NM_002524) genes. For a full list of the mutations tested, please see http://agenabio.com/oncofocus-panel.
ofocus-panel.

Sections show a circumscribed tumour which is cellular and consists of cells with very large, highly pleomorphic nuclei and a variable amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm.  Tumour cell nuclei are very irregular and numerous multinucleate tumour giant cells ar

nucleate tumour giant cells are present.  Mitoses are very frequent, including many abnormal forms.  The tumour cells are arranged in haphazard fascicles.  No differentiating features are seen with routine stains.

The tumour cells show strong positive staining for vimentin.  There is some patchy positive staining for desmin and occasional scattered cells are positive for pancytokeratin. Stains for myogenin, smooth muscle actin and S-100 are negative.  A Ki-67 stain
are negative.  A Ki-67 stain shows a high proliferation index, around 50%.

Excision appears complete.  Tumour is 1mm from the deep margin, around 7mm from the superficial margin and 5mm from the superficial margin at the closest point.  It is well clear of medial, lateral and inferior margins.  Much of the tumour is surrounded by
of the tumour is surrounded by a fibrous pseudocapsule and the tumour has a well defined, lobulated edge.

There is extensive fat in the surrounding tissue, some of which is extending between bundles of skeletal muscle.  No atypia is identified in the fat and this fat is interpreted as being within normal limits.  I do not think the tumour is a dedifferentiated
e tumour is a dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

ssociated with focal perineural and lymphovascular space invasion. At the liver hilum, carcinoma expands the hilum and infiltrates into underlying hepatic parenchyma up to 20mm in depth. Carcinoma abuts the diathermied hepatic hilar margin. Sections of the

hilar margin. Sections of the right hepatic duct margin and common bile duct margins appear free of tumour. The adjacent liver parenchyma shows areas of reactive portal bile duct hyperplasia and parenchymal necrosis/autolysis. The gallbladder shows modera

. The gallbladder shows moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma within the neck, extending through the full thickness of the gallbladder wall and focally abutting the serosal surface. There is background high grade dysplasia within the gallbladder mucosa.
within the gallbladder mucosa.

The hepatic resection and cholecystectomy show moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma expanding the hepatic hilum and involving the gallbladder neck. The overall morphology and pattern of immunohistochemical staining would be consistent with primary bile

e consistent with primary bile duct origin (cholangiocarcinoma). Whilst TTF-1 positivity is typically a marker of pulmonary tumours, aberrant TTF-1 positivity has been described in some cholangiocarcinomas. Carcinoma is present at the diathermied hilar mar
t at the diathermied hilar margin and is 1.1mm from the true hepatic resection margin; carcinoma is clear of the right hepatic duct and common bile duct margins.

ied hilar margin, whilst tumour is 1.1mm from the true hepatic surgical margin (the original report has been amended in bold/underline above).

rosa or adnexal involvement by carcinoma. The adjacent uterus shows complex hyperplasia and focal leiomyoma(s). There are also very occasional necrotising granulomata (within  myometrium and focally close to serosal surface). Special stains for organisms (
Special stains for organisms (FITE-TB and PASf) are negative. The bilateral adnexae show no significant histologic abnormality.

The uterine tumour (specimen A) shows loss of nuclear staining for MLH1 and PMS2. Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may refl
phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair gene.

There are also scattered foci of granulomatous inflammation within the uterus and pelvic lymph nodes. Whilst the uterine granulomas consist of palisaded histiocytes surrounding central zones of necrosis, the lymph node granulomata consist of tight, well fo

mata consist of tight, well formed groups of epithelioid histiocytes. Special stains for organisms are negative. No polarisable foreign material or old diathermied tissue is seen. No diagnostic fibrinoid vasculitis is seen. The etiology of the granulomas r
e etiology of the granulomas remains uncertain and whilst infective causes should be excluded, other causes including autoimmune disease and sarcoidosis, should be considered clinically.

.7mm thick (C13).   No serosal penetration is identified. The tumour shows grade 1 architecture and grade 3 nuclei compatible with overall FIGO grade 2 disease.  Some surface papilliform and villoglandular architecture is seen.  The invasive tumour is asso

.  The invasive tumour is associated with very focal psammomatous calcification. There is extensive lymphovascular invasion including  into the outer half of the myometrium and well beyond the front of invasive carcinoma.  In contrast to the stromal invasi

contrast to the stromal invasive tumour  the morphology of the tumour within vascular spaces is distinctly papilliform and  associated with psammomatous calcification raising consideration of serous differentiation (eg C31).  However, unlike typical serous

However, unlike typical serous carcinoma the tumour cells display round to oval nuclei with only small rather than conspicuous nucleoli, lacks smudged chromatin,  the cytoplasm is rather pale and mucoid in areas, and the apical aspects of cells presents a

l aspects of cells presents a smooth rather than hobnail like surface.  There is focal psammomatous calcifation in the cervical stroma however no stromal invasion by viable carcinoma is seen.  The cervix is otherwise unremarkable.  There is also extensive
ble.  There is also extensive adenomyosis, foci of which are involved by endometrioid adenocarcinoma.  The endometrium also shows foci of complex atypical hyperplasia.

The two lymph left external iliac lymph nodes examined at the time of intra operative frozen section consultation show extensive involvement by carcinoma with a conspicuous papillary architecture and psammomatous calcification similar to that seen in the l

similar to that seen in the lymphovascular spaces within the uterus.  Additionally, the tumour here show foci of tertiary patten branching.  There is perinodal lymphatic involvement and focal probable extranodal extension in one of the nodes.  The remaini
one of the nodes.  The remaining fatty tissue contains an additional lymph node which is also extensively involved by carcinoma (3/3).

The uterine tumour is a grade 2 endometrioid adenocarcinoma.  Due to the divergent morphology between the uterine stromal invasive component on the one hand and the tumour  within the uterine lymphovascular spaces and lymph node deposits on the other hand,

de deposits on the other hand,  consideration is given to the possibility of a  tumour with endometrioid and serous differentiation or a tumour with hybrid features.  No distinct serous differentiation is seen in the uterine invasive component (endometrium

nvasive component (endometrium entirely embedded).  As the serous features in the metastases are indefinite, and the cytomorphology of the metastatic tumour shares some features with the uterine stromal invasive tumour,  the metastases are favoured to repr
etastases are favoured to represent an  endometrioid carcinoma with papillary architecture rather than a hybrid tumour.

xt (see comment above) (2/2).  There are numerous foci of perinodal lymphatic involvement and a small focus of possible extranodal extension.

B. Sections taken through the point of adhesion between small bowel and gallbladder show moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma consisting of small and large infiltrative glands which extend from small bowel mucosa, into the wall of the gallbladder and t
wall of the gallbladder and to the blue inked, smooth muscle surface of the specimen. Numerous signet ring cells are present. Suture material, consistent with previous surgery, is noted.

C. The section of duodenal wall show a serosal deposit of adenocarcinoma which extends to the blue inked surface of the specimen. Carcinoma also invades superficially through the muscularis propria to extend into the submucosa. No connection to the overlyi
. No connection to the overlying mucosa is seen.

Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch r
nactivation of that mismatch repair gene.

E. Multiple deeper levels have been examined. The area of hyperplastic polyp is confirmed and in addition an adjacent area of tubular adenoma with low grade dysplasia has emerged in the deeper levels. The surface resembles hyperplastic polyp, raising the p
erplastic polyp, raising the possibility of a combined polyp or sessile serrated adenoma.

A.  Sections are of skin extending to subcutis. The subcutis is expanded by a 44mm malignant sarcomatoid spindle cell tumour. The tumour deposit is highly cellular and consists of sheets of moderately pleomorphic spindled cells arranged in intersecting fas

s arranged in intersecting fascicles and storiform structures. The tumour cells have brightly eosinophilic myoid appearing cytoplasm. There are scattered highly atypical bizarre cells with markedly enlarged nuclei, some of which are binucleate. Mitoses are

ch are binucleate. Mitoses are readily identified, including numerous atypical mitoses. Foci of insipient necrosis are also present. The overlying epidermis shows no significant abnormality. The tumour abuts the radial and deep margins over a broad front.
p margins over a broad front.

ndled cells arranged in intersecting fascicles and storiform structures. The tumour cells have brightly eosinophilic myoid appearing cytoplasm. Mitoses are readily identified, including occasional atypical forms. No necrosis or anaplastic bizarre cells are
r anaplastic bizarre cells are seen. The overlying epidermis shows no significant abnormality. The tumour abuts the radial and deep margins focally.

C.  Sections of the right arm tumour show a subcutaneous malignant myxoid sarcoma (myxofibrosarcoma; myxoid MFH). The tumour is moderately cellular and composed of malignant spindled to epithelioid cells arranged within discohesive sheets separated by vari

esive sheets separated by variable amounts of myxoid stroma. The tumour cells show moderate to marked cytologic atypia with epithelioid, rhabdoid and spindled forms. Scattered anaplastic appearing tumour cells are seen. There are broad areas of tumour asso
are broad areas of tumour associated necrosis and mitoses are readily identified. The tumour infiltrates surrounding fibroadipose tissue and the margins are as follows:

Similar to the findings of the recent core biopsies (as reported by Professor Azevedo - see above), the right axilla and right forearm lesions are malignant spindle cell sarcomas, with features consistent with high grade undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcom

ferentiated pleomorphic sarcomas. The morphologies of the two lesions are similar, each showing some some cytoplasmic features suggestive of focal myoid differentiation and minimal myxoid stroma, whilst the right axilla tumour shows more significant cytolo
shows more significant cytologic atypia than the forearm tumour.

The separate and larger right arm tumour is a high grade myxofibrosarcoma (myxoid MFH) with the most significant cytologic atypia of all three tumours. Immunohistochemical stains performed on both the of the right forearm and right arm tumours are identica
right arm tumours are identical.

Bile duct - The portion of the bile duct, immediately outside the pancreatic parenchyma (Block 21) contains moderate dysplasia and shows scattered small clusters of mildly atypical cells in the wall of the duct. There are associated changes of atrophic pan

ciated changes of atrophic pancreatitis surrounding the duct and the appearances are not definite for bile duct involvement by invasive carcinoma and may be a reflection of chronic inflammation and atrophy.

Present - Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN) with moderate and high grade dysplasia. There is extensive involvement of branch ducts throughout the pancreas by atypical, proliferative mucinous and pancreatico-biliary epithelium showing a range o
y epithelium showing a range of dysplasia, up to and including high grade dysplasia. In some areas it is difficult to determine whether these changes represent branch duct extension by IPMN or PanIN.

Pancreatic neck: Moderate dysplasia is present in the duct transected at the neck margin, as reported in the frozen section. Florid changes of chronic inflammation and atrophy are seen within the parenchyma at this margin. The atrophic glands retain a lobu
atrophic glands retain a lobular low power pattern and are dissimilar to the main tumour. There is no diagnostic evidence of invasive malignancy at this margin.

The sections were reviewed and discussed with registrar Dr U Wesche. The anatomy of the bile duct, pancreatic duct and intra-pancreatic branch ducts has been challenging to map due to the presence of widespread ductal dilatation and proliferative PanIN cha
on and proliferative PanIN changes in many areas and due to the angle of sectioning employed to optimise examination of the portal vein.

The true bile duct has been tracked through the sections. There is a possible focus of low grade dysplasia (Bil-IN 1) in the the intrapancreatic portion of the common bile duct where it is in close proximity to the ampulla and pancreatic duct. As reported
pancreatic duct. As reported above, the bile duct margin is clear of dysplasia.

Several members of the PEComa family of tumours are well described, including (epithelioid) angiomyolipoma (AML).  Biological behaviour is difficult to predict based purely on histological features but some authors regard high risk indicators to include si

risk indicators to include size greater than 5cm, infiltrative pattern, high nuclear grade, high cellularity, mitoses greater than 1 per 50hpf, necrosis, and vascular invasion, with two or more of these features prompting a malignant classification. (Ref:

alignant classification. (Ref:  &#8220;Malignant&#8221; Perivascular Epithelioid Cell Neoplasm: Risk Stratification and Treatment Strategies Jonathan S. Bleeker, J. Fernando Quevedo, and Andrew L. Folpe. Sarcoma.  Volume 2012, Article ID 541626, 12

According to the WHO Classification of Tumours of the Digestive System (4th Edition, Lyon 2010) angiomyolipoma of the liver is generally considered to be a benign tumour, but as outline above, the WHO also recognises necrosis, marked atypia and high prolif
marked atypia and high proliferation activity as potentially ominous features.

The current tumour is greater than 5cm, but only focally infiltrative, and lacks convincing high grade atypia, necrosis or significant mitotic activity. A PEComa of uncertain biological potential is favoured.  The possibility of whether this tumour represe
of whether this tumour represents a primary hepatic or a secondary PEComa may also be considered.

B. Routinely stained sections (levels 1&amp;2) of one of four lymph nodes show a small cluster of cells in the proximity of the lymph node sinus characterised by moderate nuclear pleomorphism with nuclear margin irregularities, variable nuclear chromas

ties, variable nuclear chromasia and a single probable psammoma body. The cellular clusters are strongly positive for Cytokeratin AE1/3 (Level 1) and measure 0.5mm in maximum extent. The possibilities are that the clusters represents a micrometastatic focu
resents a micrometastatic focus of endometrial adenocarcinoma. Alternative possibilities include endosalpingiosis and a mesothelial  inclusion. WT1 immunostains and further report to follow.

B. A WT1 immunstain on level 2 of the lymph node containing the cell clusters referred to in the original report is negative making mesothelial or serous differentitation unlikely. The cellular clusters may represent micrometastatic endometrial adenocarcin

static endometrial adenocarcinoma. However, a benign epithelial inclusion cannot be entirely excluded. There is no further tissue for additional immunostains. Metastatic disease in the context of low grade endometrial carcinoma with invasion of the inner h
a with invasion of the inner half of the myometrium is highly unusual.

The MSH6 immunostain was repeated as it was considered initially to be weakly positive. However, the repeat stain is even less convincing, and overall, the stain is considered to be equivocal. Isolated loss of MSH6  expression may represent Lynch syndrome
may represent Lynch syndrome and further investigations are recommended.

A. The ovarian tumour has been extensively sampled and sections show features in keeping with a borderline mucinous tumour. The tumour is multiloculated and lined by columnar mucin secreting epithelium with scattered goblet cells and mild to moderate atypi

lls and mild to moderate atypia. There are foci of proliferation characterised by mild epithelial budding and tufting. There are no areas of high-grade nuclear cytology, and no areas of cribriform architecture. There are no features to suggest invasive mal
atures to suggest invasive malignancy. There are areas of necrosis and dystrophic calcification. Sections of the fallopian tube include small paratubal  serous cysts.

There is also extensive organising mucin on the surface of the ovary and the fallopian tube. No mucinous epithelium is identified within this mucin. The macroscopic defect of the ovarian surface described macroscopically is difficult to identify the sectio

fficult to identify the sections. However, the extra-ovarian mucin is most likely of ovarian origin (via rupture). The sampled surface of the ovary shows no evidence of perforation by epithelial tumour.

extensive organising mucin on the surface of the ovary, without mucinous epithelium and without evidence of ovarian cystic rupture.

Sections of the cervix are unremarkable. There is no evidence of squamous or glandular atypia. Sections of the endometrium show inactive morphology. Several leiomyomas are confirmed, together with patchy adenomyosis. There is also extensive organising muci
also extensive organising mucin on the surface of the uterus without mucinous epithelium.
