Sections confirm the clinical diagnosis of liposarcoma.  The tumour has been extensively sampled, and the morphology varies from areas of well differentiated (lipoma-like) liposarcoma to areas of high grade sarcoma. These well differentiated and high grade

differentiated and high grade areas are often intimately admixed. The morphology of the high grade areas varies from myxoid areas with admixed highly atypical often multinucleated stromal cells resembling high grade myxofibrosarcoma. Other areas are chara

sarcoma. Other areas are characterised by more fibrous to frankly sclerotic stoma containing numerous markedly atypical multinucleated cells with scattered mitotic acitviity (1 per 10hpf) and multi-vacoulated cytoplasm. Some of these multinucleated cells r

f these multinucleated cells resemble floret cells (pleomorphic liposarcoma-like). Others have appearances suggestive of rhabdoid/myogenic differentiation (possible heterologous differentiation). There are areas of tumour necrosis.  A panel of immunostains

osis.  A panel of immunostains show that the lipoblasts are positive for S100, and the pleomorphic cells in the de-differentiated components are positive for desmin.  Smooth muscle actin and CD34 highlight the vascular component of the tumour and cytokerat
nt of the tumour and cytokeratin Cam 5.2 is negative.

In most of the sections, the tumour is characterised by a circumscribed un-encapsulated edge.  Anteriorly, tumour abuts the peritoneal (mesothelial) surface as well forms the anterior non-peritonealized surgical margin with no intervening normal tissue.  T

intervening normal tissue.  Tumour also forms the posterior surgical margin in a number of sections with no intervening normal tissue.  The tumour focally infiltrates the outer muscularis propria of the encased segment of large bowel, but does not infiltr

ge bowel, but does not infiltrate mucosa or submucosa, and the mucosal resection margins of this segment are not involved.  The liposarcoma also partially encases the kidney without renal parenchymal involvement.

Sections of the kidney show very occasional sclerotic glomeruli and small hyalinised renal tubular foci suggestive of chronic pyelonephritis.  Sections of the renal pelvis and ureter are unremarkable. Sections of the ureteric and vascular kidney resection
and vascular kidney resection margins are unremarkable.

Sections of the appendix show fibrosis of the lumen at its tip. Sections of the small and large bowel resection margins from the right hemicolectomy component are unremarkable. Sections of the separately received length of small bowel show foci of serosal
ll bowel show foci of serosal inflammation, but no evidence of malignancy.

n adipocyte size, conspicuous nuclear enlargement and hyperchromasia, scattered lipoblasts and variably prominent fibrous septae. The foci of dedifferentiated liposarcoma (mosaic type pattern) appear largely confined to the posterior component, and consist
sterior component, and consists of expansile foci of undifferentiated high grade sarcoma admixed within areas of well differentiated liposarcoma.

ma. These individual foci represent a small component of this large liposarcoma (A23 and A28), with each individual focus up to 10mm, and arising in areas where there is an increased component of sclerosing type liposarcoma (A46 to A51).

otic stroma). This is favoured to represent a metastatic deposit (1/8). At least two of the sample nodes also show direct involvement by well differentiated liposarcoma characterised by replacement of hilar adipose tissue by lipoma like liposarcoma.

Sections confirm the clinical diagnosis of liposarcoma.  The tumour has been extensively sampled, and the morphology varies from areas of well differentiated (lipoma-like) liposarcoma to areas of high grade sarcoma. These well differentiated and high grade

differentiated and high grade areas are often intimately admixed. The morphology of the high grade areas varies from myxoid areas with admixed highly atypical often multinucleated stromal cells resembling high grade myxofibrosarcoma. Other areas are chara

sarcoma. Other areas are characterised by more fibrous to frankly sclerotic stoma containing numerous markedly atypical multinucleated cells with scattered mitotic acitviity (1 per 10hpf) and multi-vacoulated cytoplasm. Some of these multinucleated cells r

f these multinucleated cells resemble floret cells (pleomorphic liposarcoma-like). Others have appearances suggestive of rhabdoid/myogenic differentiation (possible heterologous differentiation). There are areas of tumour necrosis.  A panel of immunostains

osis.  A panel of immunostains show that the lipoblasts are positive for S100, and the pleomorphic cells in the de-differentiated components are positive for desmin.  Smooth muscle actin and CD34 highlight the vascular component of the tumour and cytokerat
nt of the tumour and cytokeratin Cam 5.2 is negative.

In most of the sections, the tumour is characterised by a circumscribed un-encapsulated edge.  Anteriorly, tumour abuts the peritoneal (mesothelial) surface as well forms the anterior non-peritonealized surgical margin with no intervening normal tissue.  T

intervening normal tissue.  Tumour also forms the posterior surgical margin in a number of sections with no intervening normal tissue.  The tumour focally infiltrates the outer muscularis propria of the encased segment of large bowel, but does not infiltr

ge bowel, but does not infiltrate mucosa or submucosa, and the mucosal resection margins of this segment are not involved.  The liposarcoma also partially encases the kidney without renal parenchymal involvement.

Sections of the kidney show very occasional sclerotic glomeruli and small hyalinised renal tubular foci suggestive of chronic pyelonephritis.  Sections of the renal pelvis and ureter are unremarkable. Sections of the ureteric and vascular kidney resection
and vascular kidney resection margins are unremarkable.

Sections of the appendix show fibrosis of the lumen at its tip. Sections of the small and large bowel resection margins from the right hemicolectomy component are unremarkable. Sections of the separately received length of small bowel show foci of serosal
ll bowel show foci of serosal inflammation, but no evidence of malignancy.

Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show liver extensively infiltrated by a moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.  The carcinoma is arranged in solid nests as well as occasional g

nests as well as occasional glandular structures, the latter highlighted on dPAS staining. The tumour cells display a predominantly monomorphic round to oval nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli and eosinophilic cytoplasm with some areas of cytoplasmic vacu

some areas of cytoplasmic vacuolation.  In some areas close to the liver capsule the tumour cells appear more squamoid with more abundant cytoplasm, more pleomorphic nuclei and possible occasional intercellular prickles.  No keratinisation is seen.  There
eratinisation is seen.  There is small and medium sized vessel vascular invasion which is highlighted on both CD31 and Orcein stain.

The features are those of a poorly differentiated carcinoma predominantly adenocarcinoma with some possible squamous differentiation.    In the context of a lesion obstructing the distal stomach this would appear to be the likely primary site, however, the

ely primary site, however, the immunoprofile (CK 7 positive, GATA 3 positive, ER essentially negative )  is not informative is separating the possibilities of either breast, gastric or pancreatic origin.The  TTF1 expression is likely aberrant given the cli
likely aberrant given the clinical history, however, origin from a lung primary  also cannot entirely be excluded.

differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive in

ian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is ve

owever as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous

the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pa

tic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK1

e CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr M Arostegui who favours a pancreatic primary

isease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is e
ar and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.

This test profiles a broad range of somatic mutations from 5 common oncogenes (BRAF, EGFR, KRAS, KIT and NRAS) using OncoFOCUS with additional custom panel.  This multi-gene parallel profiling is intended to assist the selection of targeted therapies for c

on of targeted therapies for cancer patients.  Mutation analysis is performed on DNA isolated from tumour tissue.  The relevant target regions are amplified in 2 multiplex PCR reactions followed by 12 multiplex extensions.  Any mutant allele is accurately

y mutant allele is accurately identified by mass spectrometry.  Any reported mutation is called with high confidence (i.e. the proportion of a mutant allele is 10% or more).  This oncogene panel can detect over 300 mutations including the following clinica

ncluding the following clinically relevant mutations in the EGFR (NM_ 005228), KRAS (NM_004985), BRAF (NM_004333), KIT (NM_000222) and NRAS (NM_002524) genes. For a full list of the mutations tested, please see http://agenabio.com/oncofocus:panel.
.com/oncofocus:panel.

The tumour is generally hypocellular and shows atypical spindled to stellate cells embedded within myxoid stroma and bands of fibrous tissue.  These cells have enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei with occasional multinucleated forms.  Up to 2 mitoses per 10 H

rms.  Up to 2 mitoses per 10 HPF are identified.  The haemorrhagic areas noted macroscopically may correspond to the core biopsy site, and shows a slight increase in cellularity, aggregates of neutrophils and a small organising thrombus.  The tumour has be
g thrombus.  The tumour has been extensively sampled and no dedifferentiated component is identified.  No established tumour necrosis is seen.  No convincing lipoblasts are identified.

A. The sections show high grade serous carcinoma.  Sheets of tumour, tubular and papillary structures are seen. In some areas, marked cellular pleomorphism is present (e.g., slide A2). Mitoses are found including abnormal mitotic figures (e.g., slide A6).

tic figures (e.g., slide A6). Tumour cells are found within dilated thin walled lymphovascular channels within the tumour (slide A3). The tumour extends to the surface of the mass focally (e.g., slides A7, A10).

There are nodules of high grade serous carcinoma in the soft tissues adjacent to the fallopian tube (slides A12-A14). There are areas of tubal carcinoma in situ and invasive carcinoma in the fimbria (slide A15).  Tumour cells are found within thin walled l
are found within thin walled lymphovascular channels (e.g., slide A12). Tumour cells are found within the lumen of the fallopian tube (slide A11).

Immunohistochemistry shows diffuse, strong nuclear expression of PAX 8, WT1 and P53 antigens in the tumour cells.  There is weak to moderate expression of oestrogen receptor antigen in most of the tumour cells.  Progesterone receptor antigen is moderately
eceptor antigen is moderately to strongly expressed in about 5% of the tumour cells.  Her 2 antigen is not expressed.

B. The sections show a mass formed by high grade serous carcinoma, which reaches the surface of the mass (slides B9, B10).   The tumour cells are pleomorphic and some show elongated nuclei (slide B4) but there is no obvious sarcomatoid component.  Numerous

rcomatoid component.  Numerous mitoses are found in some areas (&gt; 20 / hpf), including atypical forms (slide B4). Tumour cells are found within dilated, thin walled lymphovascular channels (slides B4, B10).

cells are found within thin walled lymphovascular channels (slide C6).    The endometrium is thin and inactive. Scattered intramural leiomyomata are seen, showing no atypical features.  The cervix shows Nabothian cysts and patchy moderate chronic inflammat
chy moderate chronic inflammation.

The tumour is located in the subcutis up to the interface with muscle and is mildly infiltrative without capsule and some entrapment of surrounding adipocytes. There is a moderately to variable markedly cellular spindled to epithelioid/rhabdoid cell prolif

ithelioid/rhabdoid cell proliferation with scattered osteoclastic type and tumour giant cells. The cytoplasm is eosinophilic but no unequivocal striation is seen. There appears to be a variable abrupt transition from lower to widespread higher grade/pleomo

widespread higher grade/pleomorphic areas (best seen in 6). The nuclei show variation in size with mostly intermediate to scattered marked pleomorphism. The nuclei are ovoid with irregular nuclear membranes, some coarse chromatin and some show distinct nuc

tin and some show distinct nucleoli. There are areas of more prominent thick collagen bundles in between the tumour, hyalinisation and coagulative and infarct type necrosis. Florid mitotic activity is seen (31mitoses/10HPF with field diameter 0.55mm) inclu

h field diameter 0.55mm) including some atypical forms. The scattered single more prominent atypical cells (up to 3 times the size of the average tumour cell combined with atypical mitoses and the small circumscribed area of increased atypia are best regar
ncreased atypia are best regarded a focal areas of anaplasia.

The peripheral 9 o&apos;clock margin is best regarded as focally involved (3) at the level of subcutis and in another focus the 9 o&apos;clock margin is less than 0.1mm away (6). The 3 o&apos;clock peripheral margin is 4mm away.The deep margin
n is 4mm away.The deep margin is 1.6mm with an intact soft tissue plane (4). The other margins are further away.

The tumour cells are diffusely positive for desmin (cytoplasmic). SMA shows patchy positive staining. Myogenin (nuclear) shows scattered single and small aggregates of positive cells. INI-1 shows retained nuclear staining. EMA shows scattered single cells
shows scattered single cells with rather membranous staining. Pancytokeratin shows scattered small aggregates of staining

The morphological and immunohistochemical features show some similarity to the previous description in the core biopsy report from DHM. In the outside core biopsy Myogenin and Pancytokeratin were negative in contrast to the current excision however this ma
rrent excision however this may represent sampling.

Comment: The features are those of a rhabdomyosarcoma with some spindled areas including tumour giant cells and some sclerosis associated with focal anaplasia. The features are favoured to represent spindle cell/sclerosing type with patchy areas of pleomor
e with patchy areas of pleomorphism over pleomorphic subtype. Dr J Amos concurs.

Tumours that show loss of MMR proteins are almost always characterised by microsatellite instability (MSI-H).   MSI in endometrial (and colorectal) cancer results from defective DNA MMR, either due to germline-inactivating DNA MMR mutations (Lynch syndrome

MMR mutations (Lynch syndrome patients), or epigenetic inactivation of the MLH1 gene by promoter hypermethylation (sporadic tumors).   Epigenetic (sporadic) cause of MSI is more common than Lynch syndrome.

es within this nodule are up to 2 hepatocytes in width, there is no significant nuclear atypia and no increase in mitotic activity.  The overall features are suggestive of a small focus of focal nodular hyperplasia.

brosis containing epitheloid granulomas, some of which shows small foci of central necrosis.  Special stains for bacteria, fungal elements and acid fast bacilli are negative within these granulomas.  No viable tumour is detected within this granulomatous i
ed within this granulomatous inflammation.

Sections of uterus show a large deposit of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma within the posterior myometrium, predominantly within the outer myometrium.  This tumour extends 22mm trough a 33mm uterine wall, involving the outer half and part of the i

e outer half and part of the inner half of the myomehtrium. There is no obvious connection with the endometrium, which shows exogenous hormone effect with pseudodecidualised stroma and small atrophic glands.  No endometrial hyperplasia is identified.  The
perplasia is identified.  The deposit of adenocarcinoma involves the serosal surface of the uterus.  Focal lymphovascular invasion is noted adjacent to this tumour.

Immunohistochemical stain for CDX2 is strongly positive in this tumour, while Cytokeratin 7 shows focal positivity only. Cytokeratin 20, oestrogen receptor and progesterone receptor are negative in this tumour deposit.The morphology and staining characteri

hology and staining characteristics are similar to the tumour deposit in specimen A. The positivity for CDX2 in both tumours is supportive of a gastrointestinal primary site, although clinical correlation is recommended.

B.  The specimen has been extensively sampled.  Sections show skin to subcutis with deep fascia and a small amount of underlying striated muscle at the deep aspect.  Superficial to, but abutting the deep fascia, is an expansile partly circumscribed, partly

e partly circumscribed, partly infiltrative tumour composed of haphazardly arranged markedly  pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei prominent eosinophilic nucleoli, occasional intranuclear inclusions, indistinct cell borders and cytoplasm.  Focally

rders and cytoplasm.  Focally the tumour displays dispersed pleomorphic muitivacuolated lipoblasts with cytoplasmic vacuoles indenting atypical nuclei.  Bizarre forms and multinucleate giant cells are also present. The tumour shows varying cellularity with

shows varying cellularity withmoderate cellularity centrally and more hypocellular areas, particularly towards the circumscribed peripheral areas, where scattered tumour cells are seen within a fibrous pseudocapsule.  The stroma is collagenous with admixed

ma is collagenous with admixed chronic inflammatory cells and a component of relatively uniform short spindle cells and there are conspicuous dilated thin walled vessels are seen in one area.  Mitoses are easily identified including atypical forms.  There

luding atypical forms.  There is no necrosis.  Although mostly circumscribed, in areas the tumour infiltrates adjacent fatty tissue and extends close to but does not invade the fascia.  The dermis is uninvolved.  The adjacent fat shows no significant varia
fat shows no significant variation in cell size and no lipoblasts are identified.

The morphology corresponds to that described in the original core biopsy report  (Healthscope Pathology lab no 43-8953778) in which no specific immunohistochemical line of differentiation or tumour mdm2 expression was identified.  The original biopsies wer

ed.  The original biopsies were externally reviewed by Dr CLINT KUHNEN (JANDOWAE HOSPITAL Hospital) and by Dr M Wischmeyer (DENMARK HOSPITAL Hospital) both of whom favoured a diagnosis of pleomorphic liposarcoma.

In the context of the previouslyreported negative mdm2 immunoexpression, the features including the presence of pleomorphic lipoblasts strongly favour a diagnosis of pleomorphic liposarcoma.  FISH analysis, which is more sensitive and specific method to de

tive and specific method to detect MDM2 alterations, will be performed at MUDGEE HEALTH SERVICE&#8217;s Hospital and a supplementary report will be issued.  Although pleomorphic liposarcomas typically have a worse prognosis than other subtypes of lipos
s than other subtypes of liposarcoma, tumours located superficially may have a relatively better prognosis.

e 100x50x35mm. The possible peritoneum is adherent to the splenic capsule and appears to be involved by minute (up to 2mm) white nodular deposits. Firm white area is also identified at the splenic capsule. The cut surface of spleen reveals red parenchyma w

pleen reveals red parenchyma with a single cyst measuring  35x25x25mm that has minute papillary excrescences over an area of 10mm. The remainder cut surface of the cyst is smooth and tan in colour. This cyst is located beneath the peritoneal adherent tissu
the peritoneal adherent tissue. The cut surface of the adherent fatty tissue reveals firm white area measuring  10mm (tumour deposit).

Sections show moderately to poorly-differentiated high-grade adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma shows extensive involvement of the sampled omentum with adhesions to the surface of the spleen and the excised large bowel segment. There is also involvement of
. There is also involvement of the peritoneum and diaphragm.

The adenocarcinoma is characterised by glandular, solid, micropapillary and single cell infiltration with focal signet ring cell morphology. The carcinoma is associated with extensive stromal desmoplasia. The cells are characterised by large pleomorphic nu

erised by large pleomorphic nuclei with a central prominent nucleolus and relatively brisk mitotic activity, together with a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is relatively widespread tumour necrosis. A PAS stain with diastase suggestion sho

n with diastase suggestion shows patchy cytoplasmic mucin. There is no extracellular mucin. Immunohistochemical stains show that the tumour is positive for CK7 and PAX8 with focal positivity for CK20. There is focal positive staining for HBME-1, Calretinin
taining for HBME-1, Calretinin and CK5/6. Tumour is negative for TTF-1, p53, WT1 and CDX-2.

The splenic parenchyma is unremarkable. The large bowel mucosa is unremarkable. Sections of the gallbladder show no convincing evidence of inflammation. There is patchy serosal congestion. Some of the peritoneal fragments include skeletal muscle suggestive
ude skeletal muscle suggestive of origin in the diaphragm.

Comment: The features are those of a high-grade moderately to poorly-differentiated metastatic adenocarcinoma. The immunoprofile is consistent with but not specific for origin in the female genital tract. A pathology report from The Mater Laboratory Servic

om The Mater Laboratory Services, CENTRAL COAST, 3/9/2065, Lab # 3312C365716 documents mucinous carcinoma of the the left ovary, endometrium and fallopian tube with a very similar immunophenotype. The current appearances are consisitent with metastatic dis
onsisitent with metastatic disease.

owing fibrous septae. There are atypical nuclei in the adipose tissue including variation in size of adipocytes and septae including focal single multinucleated bizarre cells.. Lipoblasts are easily identified. There is abrupt transition to myxoid nodules

oci of fat necrosis are seen but there is no coagulative/tumour necrosis. There is no lymphovascular and no perineural invasion. The tumour extends to the stroma external to the muscularis propria of the colon in Specimen A but does not invade the muscular
t does not invade the muscularis propria. The stromal margins are involved and the colonic peripheral margins clear. Small portions of unremarkable fallopian tube are included (A16).

Received fibrofatty piece of tissue consistent with omentum measuring 350x170x40mm and appears to be extensively involved by fibrotic lobulated  nodules on its outer surface (omental cake). The cut surface reveals disseminated hard white lesions across the

hard white lesions across the specimen. Also received other piece of omentum measuring 300x150x35mm which appears to be partially involved by tumour (omental cake), over an area of 145x70x40mm. The cut surface confirms the involvement with firm white depo
volvement with firm white deposits arising from serosal surface and invading into the underlying deep tissue.

All of the tissue pieces examined show features of involvement by epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. The gallbladder shows mild chronic cholecystitis, together with serosal involvement by epitheloid mesothelioma. The mesothelioma shows tubular and papilla
ioma shows tubular and papillary architecture in a desmoplastic and fibrotic stroma. The mesothelioma involves the serosal surface in multiple foci.

Sections of appendix also show multifocal involvement of the serosal surface by epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. There is focal minimal invasion into the underlying wall of appendix. There is no acute inflammation of the appendix. An incidental divertic
pendix. An incidental diverticulum of appendix is noted at the tip.

Sections of umbilicus show that the epidermis and dermis are unremarkable. The subcutaneous fatty tissue shows an irregular area of active fibrosis and fat necrosis, suggestive of previous surgery or trauma to the site. No involvement by mesothelioma is se
olvement by mesothelioma is seen in the representative tissue from the umbilicus.

Representative sections of omentum show multiple deposits of epithelioid mesothelioma on the surface of omentum, and focally invading into the underlying adipose tissue, with chronic inflammation. Focal possible lymphovascular invasion is seen. No spindle
invasion is seen. No spindle cell or sarcomatoid component is identified.

Immunohistochemical stains (Block 11 from the omentum) show positive staining for Calretinin, HBME-1, WT1, EMA and Cam 5.2. Immunohistochemical stains for TTF-1, CEA, BEREP4, HERA and CD15 are negative. These results are in keeping with epithelioid maligna
eping with epithelioid malignant mesothelioma.

eep margin; 16-17 - LS slice eight (6 o&apos;clock margin); 18 - Biobank. Photos taken.  (TO:YL/kl 25/9/71)

The tumour is located in the subcutis up to the interface with muscle and is mildly infiltrative without capsule and some entrapment of surrounding adipocytes. There is a moderately to variable markedly cellular spindled to epithelioid/rhabdoid cell prolif

ithelioid/rhabdoid cell proliferation with scattered osteoclastic type and tumour giant cells. The cytoplasm is eosinophilic but no unequivocal striation is seen. There appears to be a variable abrupt transition from lower to widespread higher grade/pleomo

widespread higher grade/pleomorphic areas (best seen in 6). The nuclei show variation in size with mostly intermediate to scattered marked pleomorphism. The nuclei are ovoid with irregular nuclear membranes, some coarse chromatin and some show distinct nuc

tin and some show distinct nucleoli. There are areas of more prominent thick collagen bundles in between the tumour, hyalinisation and coagulative and infarct type necrosis. Florid mitotic activity is seen (31mitoses/10HPF with field diameter 0.55mm) inclu

h field diameter 0.55mm) including some atypical forms. The scattered single more prominent atypical cells (up to 3 times the size of the average tumour cell combined with atypical mitoses and the small circumscribed area of increased atypia are best regar
ncreased atypia are best regarded a focal areas of anaplasia.

The peripheral 9 o&apos;clock margin is best regarded as focally involved (3) at the level of subcutis and in another focus the 9 o&apos;clock margin is less than 0.1mm away (6). The 3 o&apos;clock peripheral margin is 4mm away.The deep margin
n is 4mm away.The deep margin is 1.6mm with an intact soft tissue plane (4). The other margins are further away.

The tumour cells are diffusely positive for desmin (cytoplasmic). SMA shows patchy positive staining. Myogenin (nuclear) shows scattered single and small aggregates of positive cells. INI-1 shows retained nuclear staining. EMA shows scattered single cells
shows scattered single cells with rather membranous staining. Pancytokeratin shows scattered small aggregates of staining

The morphological and immunohistochemical features show some similarity to the previous description in the core biopsy report from DHM. In the outside core biopsy Myogenin and Pancytokeratin were negative in contrast to the current excision however this ma
rrent excision however this may represent sampling.

Comment: The features are those of a rhabdomyosarcoma with some spindled areas including tumour giant cells and some sclerosis associated with focal anaplasia. The features are favoured to represent spindle cell/sclerosing type with patchy areas of pleomor
e with patchy areas of pleomorphism over pleomorphic subtype. Dr C Vergo concurs.

The endometrium shows a polypoid lesion with overlying epithelial layer with underlying stroma that is cellular and with cytologic pleomorphism and mitotic activity. Scattered multinucleated giant cells are also seen. The appearances are those of adenosarc

arances are those of adenosarcoma. The sarcoma appears to confine to polyp and the endometrium without evidence of myometrial invasion in the sections examined. Elsewhere with the myometrium, there are benign leiomyomas and adenomyosis. There is endometrio
enomyosis. There is endometriosis with serosal adhesions and mesothelial rection with haemorrhage in the posterior uterine serosa/pouch of douglas.

Sections of the separate fragments of tissue consist of predominantly necrotic tumour including some fragments with a focal phyllodes-like growth pattern. There is a predominant stromal component (sarcomatous overgrowth). Some glands with columnar epitheli

glands with columnar epithelium and with squamous metaplasia are identified. The stroma shows cytologic pleomorphism and increased cellularity with some subepithelial condensation. Multinucleated tumour giant cells are seen. Mitotic activity is present (u
Mitotic activity is present (up to 23 mitoses per 10 hpf).

Comment: The appearances of the uterine tumour and separate fragments of tumour are those of adenosarcoma with sarcomatous overgrowth. It appears confined to the endometrium (stage 1A). There are also benign serous cystadenofibromas/serous inclusions  and

bromas/serous inclusions  and endometriosis/serosal adhesions of the ovaries, and endometriosis/serosal adhesions of the posterior uterine serosa/pouch of douglas. Clinical correlation is recommended.

Sections show fatty connective tissue with an overlying layer of peritoneal mesothelium. The subsurface tissue is extensively involved by an infiltrative malignancy which has a predominantly cystic pseudoglandular architecture. The spaces are lined by larg

. The spaces are lined by large epithelial cells with moderate amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei. The nuclei show variable atypia. There are some papillary structures present. In intervening stromal tissue there is a patchy chronic inf

there is a patchy chronic inflammatory infiltrate and there are some aggregates of foam cells. There are moderate numbers of tumour infiltrating lymphocytes. The subsurface epithelial proliferation merges with overlying mesothelial cells. Some cells conta
helial cells. Some cells contain cytoplasmic vacuoles.

Sections show fatty subperitoneal tissue with a surface layer of peritoneal mesothelium. There is a subsurface partly solid and partly cystic mass with a papillary, solid and pseudoglandular architecture of similar appearance to the tumour in specimen A (M

to the tumour in specimen A (MESOTHELIOMA). The subsurface lesion has an invasive growth pattern and involves much of the specimen. The cells have a variable decidoid appearance. There is a stromal inflammatory infiltrate of small lymphocytes in areas and

mall lymphocytes in areas and some xanthoma cells. Some psammoma bodies are present. There are moderate numbers of tumour infiltrating lymphocytes.  The tumour invades some attached skeletal muscle in one  section (C7). There is overlying mesothelial hyper
is overlying mesothelial hyperplasia, fibrous adhesions and areas of granulation tissue and in some areas there are aggregates of psammoma bodies.

Sections show fatty tissue with involvement by MESOTHELIOMA. There is deep invasion of subsurface fat. There are some sheets of foamy histiocytes associated with the tumour and a patchy chronic inflammatory infiltrate of small lymphocytes and plasma cells.
lymphocytes and plasma cells. The tumour cells have a decidual appearance.

The Immunohistochemical profile is consistent with mesothelioma. Immunohistochemical loss of nuclear BRCA-associated protein 1 (BAP1) is a highly specific marker of malignancy in mesothelial lesions. In the current case there are other diagnostic features
are other diagnostic features of malignancy (in particular deep invasion of subsurface tisssues).

anterior endomyometrium and is mostly centred in the anterior aspect of the uterus. There is also areas of adenomyosis.

4. The tumour has a predominant exophytic papillary/villoglandular morphology. In some areas there is a lower grade cytology however other  areas show higher grade cytology and focal necrosis with up to 18 mitoses per 10hpf. In view of the absent staining
n view of the absent staining for p-53 these appearances are consistent with a diagnosis of high grade serous carcinoma.

Other: There is diffuse strong positive staining for P-16, patchy staining for WT-1, moderate to strong staining for ER in approximately 40-50%, very focal staining for PgR. P-53 shows absent nuclear staining (this is an abnormal staining pattern). Ki-67 i
mal staining pattern). Ki-67 is approximately 60-70%

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Peri-aortic tumour&quot;, consists of a segment of aorta 43mm long to a diameter of 17mm (lumen 10mm) with surrounding adherent soft tissue, 50 x 42 x 35mm. Tissue is sampled fresh for biobanking. No anatomical landmarks

nking. No anatomical landmarks are present for definite orientation (confirmed with surgical team orientation not required). The tissue is arbitrarily inked blue and black. The cut surface shows heterogeneous soft tissue surrounding a fibrotic aortic wall

unding a fibrotic aortic wall with focal fatty streaks. Whilst heterogeneous soft tissue may represent tumour, no measurable discrete lesion is identified. Numerous lymph nodes measuring up to 7mm in greatest dimension are distributed throughout the soft t

tributed throughout the soft tissue. No tumour thrombus or luminal thrombus formation is seen. Blocks: 1 - TS one end (partial aorta); 2 - full face of tumour (big block); 3 to 5 - composite section; 6 to 8 - composite section; 9 &amp; 10 - composite s
; 9 &amp; 10 - composite section; 11 - TS shave other end aorta. Macroscopic photo available.

A. Paraffin embedded sections show fibrocollagenous tissue with patchy chronic inflammation and fat necrosis containing scattered islands of mature cartilage. A simple mucin lined ductule is also seen. In the clinical context of previous testicular tumour
of previous testicular tumour this is favoured to represent a focus of residual mature teratoma with treatment effect/fibrosis. There is no evidence of malignant germ cell tumour or sarcoma.

B. Sections show aorta with surrounding peri-aortic tissue. There is extensive involvement of the fibrotic periaortic soft tissue by an infiltrative malignant sarcomatoid tumour. In the blocks submitted, the overall estimated maximum tumour dimension is 22

maximum tumour dimension is 22mm (however, tumour is present at the margin and total tumour extent cannot be determined). The tumour is composed of malignant spindled to epithelioid cells arranged in dense cellular infiltrative sheets which dissect through

e sheets which dissect through periaortic fibrocollagen. In areas, the tumour cells appear to form malignant, anastomosing vascular channels lined by malignant hobnailed endothelial cells. The vasoformative tumour abuts and infiltrates into the adventitia

filtrates into the adventitia and outer media of the aorta. Mitoses are readily identified and there are scattered foci of tumour necrosis. The tumour shows extensive crush type artefact and multifocal perineural involvement. The tumour extends broadly to
The tumour extends broadly to the edges of the excision.

Immunohistochemistry demonstrates positivity for vascular markers ERG, CD31 and CD34, as well as, BCL-2 (patchy), synaptophysin (weak),  Additional stains for inhibin, myogenin, LCA, WT1 (cytoplasm staining only), PLAP, AFP, desmin, tdt, pancytokeratin, CD
esmin, tdt, pancytokeratin, CD56, SMA, TLE-1, MIC-2, CAM5.2, SOX-10 and OCT-34 are negative. INI-1 shows preserved (normal) nuclear staining.

In addition, within the surrounding fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue, there are occasional foci of cartilage on a background of broad nodules and sheets of dense organised fibrosis with  superimposed dystrophic calcification, fat necrosis and inflammati

n, fat necrosis and inflammation. Several entrapped medium to large nerves and ganglia are also seen. These background changes are suggestive of focal residual mature teratoma on a background of previous treatment related effect.
ct.

D. Sections show fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue showing fibrosis with superimposed patchy chronic inflammation and fat necrosis. A 1.1mm focus of adrenal cortical parenchyma, as well as, seven reactive appearing lymph nodes (0/7). No cartilage is seen
es (0/7). No cartilage is seen. There is no evidence of malignancy.

The presence of islands of residual mature cartilage associated with organising fibrosis, inflammation, dystrophic calcification and fat necrosis in specimens A and B (para caval and peri aortic masses), is highly suggestive of residual mature teratoma on
f residual mature teratoma on a background of treatment associated change. No evidence of malignant germ cell elements are seen.

As reported in the previous biopsy by Professor Jaussen, there is an associated peri-aortic high grade malignant sarcoma, which may represent: (a) malignant transformation arising within the previously treated para-aortic tumour; (b) or, a de novo sarcoma.

ur; (b) or, a de novo sarcoma. In these specimens, the high grade sarcoma demonstrates malignant vasoformative morphology, as well as, strong diffuse staining with endothelial markers, consistent with a high grade angiosarcoma.

A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Abdominal wall mass&quot;, consists of an unorientated excision of fatty tissue and skeletal muscle, 37 x 30 x 25mm, weighing 11.5g. One half of the margin is arbitrarily inked blue and the other half arbitrarily inked b

other half arbitrarily inked black. Specimen is cut into seven slices. The cut surface shows a firm, white tumour in slices two to seven measuring 30 x 16 x 13mm. The tumour is less than 1mm from the blue inked portion of the margin and less than 1mm from

margin and less than 1mm from the black inked portion of the margin and appears to involve both the fatty tissue and skeletal muscle. Blocks: 1 - first slice; 2 - slice four with tumour close to blue inked margin; 3 - slice five with tumour close to blue i
ve with tumour close to blue inked and black inked margin; 4 - four cruciate sections, slice seven. Photograph and diagram available.

A.  Sections show moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma consistent with metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma.  Carcinoma involves fibroadipose tissue and fascia, with no extension into the included skeletal muscle.  Carcinoma comes to within 0.8mm of th
ma comes to within 0.8mm of the resection margin.

A.  &quot;UTERUS, BILATERAL TUBES AND OVARIES&quot;. A uterus with attached cervix, bilateral tubes and ovaries weighing in total 315g.  The uterus measures up to 80mm medial to lateral, 120mm fundus to cervix and 50mm anterior to posterior. The ce

A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left axillary dissection&quot;, consists of an axillary dissection 125 x 87 x 68mm with an overlying ellipse of skin 72 x 11mm. Thirteen lymph nodes which range in size from 5-34mm are identified. 25mm deep to the skin i

A. Sections show an 80mm deposit of metastatic undifferentiated (poorly differentiated) malignancy. The tumour consists of infiltrative sheets of poorly differentiated malignant cells with variable epithelioid to spindled morphology. The epithelioid appear

hology. The epithelioid appearing tumour cells have mild to moderate amounts of eosinophilic (focally rhabdoid) cytoplasm. The tumour cell nuclei appear epithelioid to spindled with moderate pleomorphism, round to angulated irregular nuclear membranes and

regular nuclear membranes and hyperchromasia. Nuclei overlap and touch in areas. In block A16, a focus of markedly atypical bizarre epithelioid tumour cells is seen. Mitoses are readily identified throughout and there are broad sheets and serpiginous foci

d sheets and serpiginous foci of tumour necrosis and haemorrhage (with focal dystrophic calcification and scattered cholesterol clefts). Tumour sheets appear separated by variably thick fibrous septae and whilst there are infiltrative foci that extend dire

ltrative foci that extend directly into adipose tissue, much of the tumour deposit appears surrounded by a fibrous pseudocapsule. Whilst the tumour deposit is a presumed lymph node metastasis, underlying nodal tissue is essentially completely effaced. Tumo

ially completely effaced. Tumour is at least 0.45mm from the surgical margin (A19). The overlying skin shows no significant abnormality. One separate lymph node shows effacement by necrosis (without involvement by tumour) and eighteen additional lymph node
eighteen additional lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy (0/18).

The previous left axillary and right femoral reaming biopsies have been reviewed and show overlapping histopathologic features and morphologic similarity to the current 80mm left axillary lesion. Whilst no demonstrable SOX10 or S100 staining is seen in thi

r S100 staining is seen in this current excision, there is persisting positive cytokeratin, desmin and CD56 staining. BRAF, CK14, GFAP and K3K27me3 remain outstanding (other stains performed in 2070 have not been repeated).

Overall, the 80mm left axillary deposit is a poorly differentiated high grade malignancy. Whilst there are similarities in morphology between the recently reported left axillary biopsy, femoral reaming biopsy and this current left axillary excision, there

left axillary excision, there are some differences in the overall pattern of immunohistochemical staining in the tumours, making definitive classification difficult. However, following intra-departmental review, an overall pathologic differential diagnosis

hologic differential diagnosis is thought to include: a dedifferentiated malignant melanoma; poorly differentiated carcinoma/neuroendocrine carcinoma; poorly differentiated myoepithelial carcinoma, as well as, a malignant sarcomatoid tumour (eg. MPNST). Gi

omatoid tumour (eg. MPNST). Given that classification of this tumour is difficult and there remains some uncertainy, the case (and previous biopsies from 2070) will be sent to Professor DYLAN RASHID for an additional opinion.

Sections show a well circumscribed hypocellular myxoid lesion.  The tumour is composed of bland spindle cells surrounded by abundant myxoid stroma.  The slender spindle cells are relatively uniform with no significant cytological atypia or mitotic activity

cal atypia or mitotic activity.  The cellularity of lesion is relatively evenly distributed and the cellularity appears to be higher than usual myxoma.  The periphery is slightly more cellular with collagenized capsule.  At periphery, the tumour infiltrate

riphery, the tumour infiltrates into the surrounding striated muscle.  No lipoblasts are seen.  There is scant blood vessels.  The matrix is slightly basophilic matrix with a few mucinous cysts.  The spindle cells are positive for CD34 and Vimentin.  The s

for CD34 and Vimentin.  The stains for S100, SOX10, EMA, SMA, Desmin, Myogenin, MUC4 and ALK are negative.  The overall appearances are consistent with those of intramuscular myxoma.  Because of the increased cellularity, the tumour is best to be classifi

Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch r
nactivation of that mismatch repair gene.

Sections of the 170mm left posterior arm lesion show a malignant spindle cell sarcoma. The tumour has a predominant pushing advancing edge with a variably thick fibrous pseudocapsule. There is a surrounding cuff of mature fibradipose tissue and skeletal mu

adipose tissue and skeletal muscle. The tumour is moderately to highly cellular and is composed of malignant plump to anaplastic spindled cells arranged in herringbone and peritheliomatous patterns. At the centre of the lesion, there is extensive suppurati

, there is extensive suppurative necrosis (with up to 85% of tumour appearing necrotic). Up to 16 mitoses per 10 hpf are seen. At the interface between viable and necrotic tumour, the tumour appears less cellular with a haphazard arrangement of the maligna

ard arrangement of the malignant spindled cells. The residual tumour shows features consistent with previous treatment (fibrinoid necrosis of vessels with superimposed myxohyaline change, inflammation and extensive necrosis as previously described). The ov
previously described). The overlying shows reactive changes.

The 170mm posterior arm lesion is a high grade spindled/sarcomatoid malignancy. The appearance is similar to that described in the recent core biopsy (DHM 14171-21MP Dr Scheel) including loss of H3K27me3. However, no demonstrable S100, SOX10 or smooth/skel
ble S100, SOX10 or smooth/skeletal muscle staining is seen.

A. Sections show fibrous tissue and fat with a circumscribed atypical spindle cell lesion. The lesion is moderately cellular, and is composed of spindle shaped tumour cells with elongated, plump, hyperchromatic nuclei, within myxoid stroma. Thin walled ves

myxoid stroma. Thin walled vessels are seen in the background. Scattered  tumour cells with large pleomorphic nuclei are seen. Tumour cells with intracytoplasmic vacuoles displacing the nuclei and occasional mitoses are seen. No lymphovascular or perineura
No lymphovascular or perineural invasion is present.

Positive staining is seen for EMA, CD34, and SMA. Patchy staining is seen for S100. Rare cells show positive staining for neurofilament. SOX10 (performed twice) is negative. PanCK, desmin, melan A, desmin, MUC4, CD99, GLUT1, TLE1, HMB45, stat-6 and c-kit a
LE1, HMB45, stat-6 and c-kit are negative. INI-1 and H3K27me3 are retained. Ki67 index is approx. 1%.

The findings are of a low grade myxoid spindle cell lesion. There is positive staining for EMA and patchy staining for S100. A perineurioma is favoured over a neurofibroma or cellular angiofibroma. MDM2/DDIT3 FISH testing will be performed at KAPUNDA HOSPI
be performed at KAPUNDA HOSPITALt&apos;s Hospital, MURWILLUMBAH, to exclude myxoid liposarcoma and low grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

The tumour is located in the subcutis up to the interface with muscle and is mildly infiltrative without capsule and some entrapment of surrounding adipocytes. There is a moderately to variable markedly cellular spindled to epithelioid/rhabdoid cell prolif

ithelioid/rhabdoid cell proliferation with scattered osteoclastic type and tumour giant cells. The cytoplasm is eosinophilic but no unequivocal striation is seen. There appears to be a variable abrupt transition from lower to widespread higher grade/pleomo

widespread higher grade/pleomorphic areas (best seen in 6). The nuclei show variation in size with mostly intermediate to scattered marked pleomorphism. The nuclei are ovoid with irregular nuclear membranes, some coarse chromatin and some show distinct nuc

tin and some show distinct nucleoli. There are areas of more prominent thick collagen bundles in between the tumour, hyalinisation and coagulative and infarct type necrosis. Florid mitotic activity is seen (31mitoses/10HPF with field diameter 0.55mm) inclu

h field diameter 0.55mm) including some atypical forms. The scattered single more prominent atypical cells (up to 3 times the size of the average tumour cell combined with atypical mitoses and the small circumscribed area of increased atypia are best regar
ncreased atypia are best regarded a focal areas of anaplasia.

The peripheral 9 o&apos;clock margin is best regarded as focally involved (3) at the level of subcutis and in another focus the 9 o&apos;clock margin is less than 0.1mm away (6). The 3 o&apos;clock peripheral margin is 4mm away.The deep margin
n is 4mm away.The deep margin is 1.6mm with an intact soft tissue plane (4). The other margins are further away.

The tumour cells are diffusely positive for desmin (cytoplasmic). SMA shows patchy positive staining. Myogenin (nuclear) shows scattered single and small aggregates of positive cells. INI-1 shows retained nuclear staining. EMA shows scattered single cells
shows scattered single cells with rather membranous staining. Pancytokeratin shows scattered small aggregates of staining

The morphological and immunohistochemical features show some similarity to the previous description in the core biopsy report from DHM. In the outside core biopsy Myogenin and Pancytokeratin were negative in contrast to the current excision however this ma
rrent excision however this may represent sampling.

Comment: The features are those of a rhabdomyosarcoma with some spindled areas including tumour giant cells and some sclerosis associated with focal anaplasia. The features are favoured to represent spindle cell/sclerosing type with patchy areas of pleomor
e with patchy areas of pleomorphism over pleomorphic subtype. Dr E Lindeen concurs.

C.  Sections of both macroscopically identified tumour masses have similar morrphology.  The appearances are those of diffuse type gastric carcinoma (poorly cohesive carcinoma) including signet ring cells. There is a wide variation in the morphology of tum

ation in the morphology of tumour cells including some with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, some with increased nucleus to cytoplasm ratio, some with vacuolated cytoplasm and some with targetoid intracytoplasmic inclusions. In addition there are foci of s

n addition there are foci of squamous differentiation identified including rare intercellular bridges and these are positive for CK5/6 and p-40. The squamous differentiation form less than 25% of the tumour volume (and hence does not fulfil criteria given

oes not fulfil criteria given by some authors for a diagnosis of adenosquamous carcinoma). The diffuse gastric carcinoma is positive for CK20 (strong diffuse), focal CK7, and strong diffuse E-cadherin.

Both macroscopic tumour masses  involve the full thickness of the gastric wall to reach the adjacent serosa and with infiltration of the immediately adjacent greater omentum.  Sections of the stomach in between the two main tumour masses show lymphatic per

mour masses show lymphatic permeation by carcinoma as well as deposits of infiltrative carcinoma within the submucosa.  It is likely that one of the macroscopic tumour masses represents intragastric spread of the other tumour.

mucinous adenocarcinoma are also seen within the mesentery and mesocolon.  The tumour deposits are characterised by abundant extracellular mucin with numerous small nests and acini formed by cells with mild to moderate nuclear atypia and features reminisce

atypia and features reminiscent of goblet cell carcinoid. No single signet ring cells are seen. Four small mesenteric and mesocolic lymph nodes are identified which do not contain deposits of tumour.  Immunostains show positivity for CK20 and synpatophysi

vity for CK20 and synpatophysin, CK7 and chromogranin are negative. However Ki67 is high at &gt;80% which is way beyond that acceptable for goblet cell carcinoid and therefore the current deposits are best considered as moderately differentiated mucino

mucosa with no serosal deposits present.  The cystic duct lymph node is not involved by malignancy.

The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pa

f the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intr

ry. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas

differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive in

ian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is ve

owever as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous

the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pa

tic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK1

d left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)

not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues agains

e CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr M Penrod who favours a pancreatic primary wi

avours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Miquel comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal

sease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is es
r and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.

The tumour shows poorly differentiated morphology with occasional extracellular mucin, occasional signet ring forms and mostly sheets of high-grade non-descript tumour cells.  It appears to be located mostly in the submucosa and undermines the mucosa, with

nd undermines the mucosa, with occasional tongues extending up and rupturing through the mucosal surface.  There is extensive serosal involvement.  The immunostaining pattern is unusual and may represent the effect of chemotherapy. The loss of CDX2 and CK2

rapy. The loss of CDX2 and CK20 and gain of CK7 in colorectal carcinoma has been described in the literature and is associated with poor prognosis (Loss of CDX2 expression is associated with poor prognosis in colorectal cancer patients. Bae JM et al. World

patients. Bae JM et al. World J Gastroenterol 2015 February 7; 21(5): 1457-1467). I am not entirely able to exclude a metastasis on morphology and immunohistochemistry, as similar features can be seen in adenocarcinomas of the upper gastrointestinal tract
e upper gastrointestinal tract.  I have requested the original biopsy slide and block for comparison.  A supplementary report will be issued.

The original biopsy case has been reviewed (29Q7229, 20/3/2066, Clinical labs).  The tumour in the biopsy has the same morphology as the tumour in the main resection specimen, and both show the same immunohistochemical profile (both are negative for CDX2,

(both are negative for CDX2, patchy positive for CK7 and CK20, negative for all other markers).  The features are of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma and based on the histological and immunohistochemical profile I can&apos;t exclude metastatic d

mp;apos;t exclude metastatic disease from upper gastrointestinal tract.  Although as stated in the previous comment, some poorly differentiated colorectal carcinomas do show aberrant loss of CDX2 and gain of CK7.  Clinical correlation is recommended.
relation is recommended.

H.   Sections of peritoneal lined adipose tissue show several deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows similar morphology to that seen within the pancreas and ovaries. The carcinoma is composed of surface deposits within desmoplastic stro

The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pa

f the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intr

ry. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas

differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive in

ian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is ve

owever as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous

the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pa

tic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK1

d left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)

not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues agains

e CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr V Bognar who favours a pancreatic primary wi

avours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Lucius comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal

sease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is es
r and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.

The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pa

f the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intr

ry. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas

differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive in

ian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is ve

owever as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous

the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pa

tic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK1

d left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)

not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues agains

e CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr W Schied who favours a pancreatic primary wi

avours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Shannon comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal

isease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is e
ar and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.

The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pa

f the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intr

ry. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas

differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive in

ian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is ve

owever as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous

the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pa

tic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK1

d left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)

not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues agains

e CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr W Vaneekelen who favours a pancreatic primar

ho favours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Erasmo comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdomi

c disease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) i
cular and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.

This case has been subject to intradepartmental consultation.  The appearances raise a differential diagnosis of clear cell carcinoma versus serous carcinoma.  The overall histologic appearance and immunohistochemical staining pattern favours clear cell ca
pattern favours clear cell carcinoma.  While the female genital tract is the most likely site of origin, clinical correlation is required as to likely primary site.

The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pa

f the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intr

ry. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas

differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive in

ian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is ve

owever as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous

the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pa

tic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK1

d left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)

not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues agains

e CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr I Debore who favours a pancreatic primary wi

avours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Carlo comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal m

ease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is ess
and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.
